a field configuration invariant under $P_A$ obeys in particular
$$
G^1_+(x^0,x^1)+\overline{G}^1_-(x^0,-x^1)=0.
$$
Such a configuration can be considered as an extension of a configuration on
the left half-plane obeying a boundary condition at $x^1=0$
such that
$$
(G^1_++\overline{G}_-^1)|_{x^1=0}=0.
$$
The latter is the condition on D-branes to preserve an A-type supersymmetry.
Thus, {\it
a D-brane associated with an A-parity is an A-brane.}
Likewise, {\it
a D-brane associated with a B-parity is a B-brane.}

For example, let us consider a supersymmetric
sigma model on the complex plane ${\mathbb C}$,
described by a chiral superfield $\Phi$.
The transformation
$
\Phi\longrightarrow \overline{\Omega_A^*\Phi}
$
is an A-parity. The condition of invariance under this parity is
$$
\Phi=\overline{\Omega_A^*\Phi}.
$$
Such a configuration can be regarded as the smooth extension of the
configuration on the left (super) half-plane
which obeys the boundary condition
$$
~~~\Phi=\overline{\Phi} \qquad\mbox{at A-boundary}.
$$
This is nothing but the ${\mathcal N}=2_A$ preserving
boundary condition corresponding to
the D1-brane at the real line $\phi=\overline{\phi}$.

Similarly, the transformations
$
\Phi\longrightarrow \pm \Omega_B^*\Phi
$
are B-parities. Invariant configurations
$$
\Phi=\pm \Omega_B^*\Phi
$$
can be regarded as
the smooth extensions of the
configuration on the left (super) half-plane
which obey the boundary condition
$$
~~~
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
D_+\Phi=D_-\Phi\\
\Phi=0
\end{array}
\right.
\qquad\mbox{at B-boundary}.
$$
They are nothing but the ${\mathcal N}=2_B$ preserving
boundary condition corresponding to
D2-brane filling ${\mathbb C}$ or D0-brane at $\phi=0$ 
respectively.

These examples generalize to any parity symmetry of the form
$\tau\Omega$ where $\tau:X\to X$ is an antiholomorphic or
holomorphic isometry of the target K\"ahler manifold $X$.
If $\tau$ has fixed points, the corresponding boundary
condition  is the one for the D-brane wrapped on the fixed-point set
$X^{\tau}$.
If $\tau$ has no fixed point, there is no invariant configurations
and therefore no associated boundary condition.

It is important that $\tau\Omega$ is
a symmetry of the theory.
If that is anomalous, the corresponding D-brane boundary condition
is expected to suffer from some pathology.
Let us consider the example $\tau:(z_1,z_2)
\mapsto (\overline{z}_2,\overline{z}_1)$ for $X={{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n\times {{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n$,
where the two ${{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n$
have the same size and no $B$-field $t_1=t_2=r$.
The fixed-point set is
$$
X^{\tau}=\Bigl\{\,(z_1,z_2)\in {{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n\times {{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n\,|\,z_2=\overline{z}_1\,\Bigr\}
\cong {{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n.
$$
If $n$ is odd, $\tau\Omega$ is a symmetry as long as $t_1=t_2$,
and the D-brane boundary condition for $X^{\tau}$ is expected to be
good.
If $n$ is even, however, we have seen that
$\tau\Omega$ is anomalous if $t_1=t_2$.
Then, the D-brane boundary condition for $X^{\tau}$ is expected to be
bad. In fact, the quantization of open string in such examples are
studied from the point of view of
symplectic geometry \cite{FOOO}, and it was found that
definition of (a finite dimensional model of)
the open string Hilbert space suffers from a problem
if $n$ is even.\footnote{Roughly speaking, the definition involves
a study of the moduli space of holomorphic discs, and the moduli space
is required to be orientable.
If $n$ is even the moduli space is unorientable.
We thank Y.-G. Oh for explanation of this point.}
However, if we turn on a $B$-field of period $\pi$ on one of the ${{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n$ in
$X={{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n\times {{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}}^n$,
the parity anomaly is cancelled and the D-brane at $X^{\tau}$ will not suffer
from pathology. 
Pathology of $X^{\tau}$ for the case $n$ even, $t_1=t_2$, as well as
the remedy by taking $t_1=t_2+\pi i$
 will be explicitly seen in the mirror description
in Section~\ref{subsub:AsmBlg}.



\section{Orientifolds of ${\cal N}=2$ Minimal Models I}
\label{sec:Omin}

In this section, we study parity symmetries of the ${\mathcal N}=2$
minimal model. The discussion crucially depends on whether or not,
and how, GSO projection is imposed.
We introduce the model as a supersymmetric gauged WZW model where the GSO 
projection is (of course) not imposed.
We find the A and B parities of the system and compute the twisted Witten indices
for the closed string.
We then move on to the model with non-chiral GSO projection.
The procedure proposed by Pradisi, Sagnotti and Stanev (PSS)
\cite{PSS} (and established by later works
\cite{bantay,HSS,FSHSS,SaAn,BH1})
gives a prescription to construct the crosscap 
states of the GSO projected model,
and we will compute the Klein bottle amplitudes.
Then, we determine the crosscap states of the model before the GSO
projection, using the PSS procedure combined with
the supercurrent condition.
This enables us to compute the Witten indices
as well as the overlap of the crosscap states and supersymmetric ground states.

Sections \ref{sub:minimal} through \ref{sub:DOF}
 deal with the system before GSO projection, Section~\ref{sub:RCFT}
discusses the GSO projected model, and Section~\ref{sub:beGSO}
provides the relation between them.
In Section \ref{sec:OMMII}, we extend the study by including
D-branes and open strings.


\subsection{The minimal model}\label{sub:minimal}


The ${\cal N}=2$ minimal model is realized as
the $SU(2)$ WZW model and a Dirac fermion system,
which are coupled through a $U(1)$ gauge field.
Let $G=SU(2)$ and $H=U(1)\subset SO(3)$.
Let us consider a Dirac fermion
arranged into the hermitian $2\times 2$ matrix
$$
\Psi_{\pm}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0&\overline{\psi}_{\pm}\\
\psi_{\pm}&0
\end{array}
\right).
$$
It preserves its form under 
the $H$-action $\Psi_{\pm}\to h^{-1}\Psi_{\pm} h$:
the component $\psi_{\pm}$ transforms as a charge $1$ field.
We consider the system with the action
$$
S(A,g,\Psi)=kS(A,g)+{i\over 2\pi}\int_{\Sigma}
w\rm d}^2x\,{\rm tr}\left(
\Psi_-D_+\Psi_-+\Psi_+D_-\Psi_+\right),
$$
where $kS(A,g)$ is the WZW action \cite{Wnab} and
$D_{\mu}\Psi:=\partial_{\mu}\Psi+[A_{\mu},\Psi]$.
The action is invariant under the $H$-valued gauge transformation
$A\to h^{-1}Ah+h^{-1}w\rm d} h$,
$g\to h^{-1}gh$, $\Psi_{\pm}\to h^{-1}\Psi_{\pm}h$.
Under the $H$-valued constant chiral gauge transformation
fbegin{equation}
g\to h_1^{-1}gh_2,
\,\,\,
\Psi_-\to h_1^{-1}\Psi_-h_1,
\,\,\,
\Psi_+\to h_2^{-1}\Psi_+h_2,
\label{scgt}
end{equation}
the path-integral measure changes by the factor \cite{PW,GawKup}
$$
\exp\left[\,(k+2){i\over 2\pi}\int
{\rm tr}\Bigl(F_A\log(h_1h_2^{-1})\Bigr)\,\right].
$$
The origin of `$k$' in the exponent is  the change in the action
$kS(A,g)$
while `$+2$' comes from the chiral anomaly of the charged
fermion.


\subsubsection{$(2,2)$ Superconformal symmetry}


The important property of the system is
$(2,2)$ supersymmetry.
Using
$$
\eta_{\pm}
={1\over\sqrt{k}}\psi_{\pm}\sigma_-
={1\over\sqrt{k}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0&0\\
\psi_{\pm}&0
\end{array}
\right),
\,\,\,\,\,\,\,
\overline{\eta}_{\pm}
={1\over\sqrt{k}}\overline{\psi}_{\pm}\sigma_+
={1\over \sqrt{k}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0&\overline{\psi}_{\pm}\\
0&0
\end{array}
\right),
$$
the supersymmetry transformations are written as
w
&\delta g=-i\sqrt{2}\left(\,
\epsilon_+\eta_-g-\overline{\epsilon}_+\overline{\eta}_-g-\overline{\epsilon}_-g\eta_+
+\epsilon_-g\overline{\eta}_+\,\right),\nonumber\\
&\delta\eta_-=\sqrt{2}\overline{\epsilon}_+\left[D_-gg^{-1}\right]_-,
\,\,\,\,
\delta\eta_+=-\sqrt{2}\epsilon_-\left[g^{-1}D_+g\right]_-,
\label{SUSY}\\
&\delta\overline{\eta}_-=-\sqrt{2}\epsilon_+\left[D_-gg^{-1}\right]_+,
\,\,\,\,
\delta\overline{\eta}_+=\sqrt{2}\overline{\epsilon}_-\left[g^{-1}D_+g\right]_+,
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
where $[X]_{\pm}$ is the projection to the upper-right/lower-left
entry of $X$.
%This variation rule obeys the $(2,2)$ supersymmetry algebra
%\beq
%[\delta^{(1)},\delta^{(2)}]
%=2i(\epsilon_+^{(1)}\bepsilon_+^{(2)}
%-\epsilon_+^{(2)}\bepsilon_+^{(1)})\partial_-+
%2i(\epsilon_-^{(1)}\bepsilon_-^{(2)}
%-\epsilon_-^{(2)}\bepsilon_-^{(1)})\partial_+.
%\eeq
The naive chiral R-symmetry
$\psi_{\mp}\to\,{\rm e}^{\mp i\alpha_{\mp}}\psi_{\mp}$
has an anomaly, but it can be cancelled  using the
`anomalous' chiral gauge transformations (\ref{scgt}).
The following combination is anomaly-free:
fbegin{equation}
U(1)_R:\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
g\to h_{\alpha_-}^{-1}g,\\
\eta_-\to\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha_-}h_{\alpha_-}^{-1}\eta_-h_{\alpha_-},\\
\overline{\eta}_-\to\,{\rm e}^{i\alpha_-}
h_{\alpha_-}^{-1}\overline{\eta}_-h_{\alpha_-},
\end{array}
\right.
\,\,\,
U(1)_L:
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
g\to gh_{\alpha_+}^{-1},\\
\eta_+\to \,{\rm e}^{i\alpha_+}h_{\alpha_+}\eta_+h_{\alpha_+}^{-1},\\
\overline{\eta}_+\to \,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha_+}h_{\alpha_+}\overline{\eta}_+h_{\alpha_+}^{-1},
\end{array}
\right.
\label{RLR}
end{equation}
where $h_{\alpha}:=\exp(i\alpha\sigma_3/(k+2))$.
The R-symmetries are trivial at $\alpha_{\pm}=2\pi m_{\pm} (k+2)$
with $m_{\pm}\in\mathbb Z}$ since $h_{2\pi m_{\pm}(k+2)}=1$.
Note also that $(\alpha_-,\alpha_+)=(2\pi m, -2\pi m)$
with $m\in\mathbb Z}$
is gauge-equivalent to the trivial transformation.


The supercurrents and the R-currents are found by the Noether procedure.
In fact,
the left and right moving currents decouple as
$G_-^0=G_-^1=G$, $G_+^0=-G_+^1=\widetilde{G}$, and
$J_R^0=J_R^1=J$, $J_L^0=-J_L^1=\widetilde{J}$,
reflecting the
$(2,2)$ super{\it conformal} symmetry that the system actually has.
The expressions of these currents are
w
&&\overline{G}=i\sqrt{2}k\,{\rm tr}(\overline{\eta}_-D_-gg^{-1})
=\sqrt{2\over k}\overline{\psi}_-J^G(\sigma_+),
\label{Gexpr1}\\
&&G=i\sqrt{2}k\,{\rm tr}(\eta_-D_-gg^{-1})
=\sqrt{2\over k}\psi_-J^G(\sigma_-),
\\
&&\overline{\widetilde{G}}=-i\sqrt{2}k\,{\rm tr}(\eta_+g^{-1}D_+g)
=\sqrt{2\over k}\psi_+\widetilde{J}^G(\sigma_-),
\\
&&\widetilde{G}=-i\sqrt{2}k\,{\rm tr}(\overline{\eta}_+g^{-1}D_+g)
=\sqrt{2\over k}\overline{\psi}_+\widetilde{J}^G(\sigma_+),
\label{Gexpr4}\\
&&J=k\,{\rm tr}(\overline{\eta}_-\eta_-+{i\over k+2}\sigma_3(
D_-gg^{-1}+i[\overline{\eta}_-,\eta_-]))
=\overline{\psi}_-\psi_-+{1\over k+2}J^H,
\label{Rright}\\
&&\widetilde{J}=-k\,{\rm tr}(\overline{\eta}_+\eta_++{i\over k+2}\sigma_3(
D_-gg^{-1}+i[\overline{\eta}_+,\eta_-]))
=-\overline{\psi}_+\psi_+-{1\over k+2}\widetilde{J}^H.
\label{Rleft}
bbnd{eqnarray}
Here
 $J^G(X)$ and $\widetilde{J}^G(X)$ are the currents of the 
$G$-WZW sector
$$
J^G(X)=ik\,{\rm tr}(D_-gg^{-1}X),
\,\,\,\,
\widetilde{J}^G(X)=-ik\,{\rm tr}(g^{-1}D_+g X),
$$
while $J^H$ and $\widetilde{J}^H$ are ($2$ times)
the right and left components of the gauge current:
fbegin{equation}
J^H=2(J^G(\sigma_3/2)+\psi_-\overline{\psi}_-),
\,\,\,\,\,\,
\widetilde{J}^H=2(\widetilde{J}^G(\sigma_3/2)+\psi_+\overline{\psi}_+).
\label{JH}
end{equation}
By definition, R-symmetries transform the supercurrents as
$G\to \,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha_-}G, \overline{G}\to\,{\rm e}^{i\alpha_-}\overline{G}$,
$\widetilde{G}\to\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha_+}\widetilde{G},\overline{\widetilde{G}}\to\,{\rm e}^{i\alpha_+}\overline{\widetilde{G}}$.
Those that transform them 
only by sign form the subgroup $\mathbb Z}_{2(k+2)}\times \mathbb Z}_2$
generated by $(\alpha_-,\alpha_+)=(\pi,0)$
and by $(\alpha_-,\alpha_+)=(\pi,-\pi)$.
%The former has order $2(k+2)$ and 
Up to gauge transformations,
the former is equivalent to the axial rotation of order $2(k+2)$:
fbegin{equation}
a=\,{\rm e}^{-\pi iJ_0}: A\to A,\,\,\,
g\to h_{\pi\over 2}^{-1}gh_{\pi\over 2}^{-1},\,\,\,
\Psi_-\to -h_{\pi\over 2}^{-1}\Psi_-h_{\pi\over 2},\,\,\,
\Psi_+\to h_{\pi\over 2}\Psi_+h_{\pi\over 2}^{-1},
\label{axsym}
end{equation}
and the latter is
equivalent to the fermion number
fbegin{equation}
(-1)^F=\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i(J_0-\widetilde{J}_0)}:(A,g,\Psi)\to (A,g,-\Psi).
\label{mod2F}
end{equation}
We will later consider the model where $(-1)^F$ is gauged --- the model
with non-chiral GSO projection.



\subsubsection{Geometric picture}


The model has a geometrical interpretation.
We parametrize the group element by
$$
g=\,{\rm e}^{i(\phi+t)\sigma_3/3}\,{\rm e}^{i\theta\sigma_1}\,{\rm e}^{i(\phi-t)\sigma_3/2}
=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\,{\rm e}^{i\phi}\cos\theta&i\,{\rm e}^{it}\sin\theta\\
i\,{\rm e}^{-it}\sin\theta&\,{\rm e}^{-i\phi}\cos\theta
\end{array}\right),
$$
and the fermions by
w
&&\overline{\chi}_+=-\sqrt{2\over k}\,\psi_+\,{\rm e}^{it}\sin\theta,
\,\,\,
\chi_+=-\sqrt{2\over k}\,\overline{\psi}_+\,{\rm e}^{-it}\sin\theta,
\nonumber\\
&&\overline{\chi}_-=\sqrt{2\over k}\,\overline{\psi}_-\,{\rm e}^{-it}\sin\theta,
\,\,\,
\chi_-=\sqrt{2\over k}\,\psi_-\,{\rm e}^{it}\sin\theta,
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
After integrating out the gauge field, we obtain the following
action which involves $(\theta,\phi)$ or $z=\,{\rm e}^{-i\phi}\cos\theta$
but does not contain $t$:
$$
S={1\over 2\pi}\int_{\Sigma}
w\rm d}^2x\,\Bigl\{\,-g_{z\overline{z}}\partial^{\mu}z\partial_{\mu}\overline{z}
+2ig_{z\overline{z}}(\overline{\chi}_-{\cal D}_{\!+}^{}\chi_-+\overline{\chi}_+{\cal D}_{\!-}^{}\chi_+)
+R_{z\overline{z} z\overline{z}}\chi_+\chi_-\overline{\chi}_-\overline{\chi}_+
\,\Bigr\}.
$$
Here $g_{z\overline{z}}={k\over 2(1-|z|^2)}$
and ${\cal D}_{\mu}:=\partial_{\mu}+\Gamma^z_{zz}\partial_{\mu}z$.
This is the action for the supersymmetric sigma model
whose target space is the disc $|z|\leq 1$ with metric
fbegin{equation}
w\rm d} s^2=k\Bigl[\,(w\rm d}\theta)^2+\cot^2\theta(w\rm d}\phi)^2\,\Bigr]
=k{|w\rm d} z|^2\over 1-|z|^2}.
\label{disc}
end{equation}
The supersymmetry variation (\ref{SUSY}) transforms
the complex coordinate as
$\delta z=\epsilon_+\chi_--\epsilon_-\chi_+$, which shows that
$z$ and $\chi_{\pm}$ form a chiral multiplet.
The R-symmetry acts on $z$ as
$$
z\to \,{\rm e}^{i(\alpha_-+\alpha_+)/(k+2)}z.
$$






\subsection{Parity symmetry}\label{sub:pari}


Let us study the parity symmetry of the system.
The coordinate
transformation $(x^0,x^1)\to (x^0,-x^1)$ that reverses the
orientation of the worldsheet is denoted by $\Omega$. 
We have seen in \cite{BH1} that the bosonic gauged WZW model has two types of
parity invariance: $\Omega$ combined with
$(A,g)\to (A,g^{-1})$ or
$(A,g)\to (g_*^{-1}Ag_*,g_*^{-1}g^{-1}g_*)$, where
$$
g_*:=i\sigma_1=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0&i\\
i&0
\end{array}\right),\,\,\,\,
\mbox{modulo $H$-action,}
$$
extending the parity symmetries of the ordinary WZW model 
\cite{PoSt,BCW,Schel,Br} to the gauged case.
Analogs of these in the supersymmetric model
are $\Omega$ combined with
fbegin{equation}
{\cal I}_A:(A,g,\Psi)\to (A,g^{-1},\Psi)
end{equation}
and
fbegin{equation}
{\cal I}_B:(A,g,\Psi)\to
(g_*^{-1}Ag_*,g_*^{-1}g^{-1}g_*,g_*^{-1}\Psi g_*).
end{equation}
Note that $\Omega$ reverses the worldsheet chirality,
and hence it exchanges the left and  right components of the fermion $\Psi$:
$(\Omega\Psi)_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)=\Psi_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1)$.
(It also maps the gauge field as
$(\Omega A)_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)=A_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1)$, just as in the bosonic case.)
In particular,
${\cal I}_A\Omega$ and ${\cal I}_B\Omega$
act on the components $\psi_{\pm}, \overline{\psi}_{\pm}$ as
w
&&{\cal I}_A\Omega:\psi_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)\to \psi_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1),
\,\,\,
\overline{\psi}_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)\to \overline{\psi}_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1),
\label{Apsit}\\
&&{\cal I}_B\Omega:
\psi_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)\to \overline{\psi}_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1),
\,\,\,
\overline{\psi}_{\pm}(x^0,x^1)\to \psi_{\mp}(x^0,-x^1).
\label{Bpsit}
bbnd{eqnarray}
The classical action $S(A,g,\Psi)$ is invariant under both
${\cal I}_A\Omega$ and ${\cal I}_B\Omega$.
Thus, these are the candidates for parity symmetry of the
supersymmetric model.


\subsubsection{Parity anomaly}\label{subsub:panomaly}

Let us examine whether there is an anomaly from the fermionic sector.
We recall that there are fermionic zero modes in a background $A$
in which the first Chern class
$$
c_1={i\over 2\pi}\int_{\Sigma}{\rm tr}\left(F_A
(\mbox{${-1\over 2}$}\sigma_3)\right)
$$
is non-zero.
If it is positive,  
there are generically $c_1$ zero modes for both $\psi_-$ and $\overline{\psi}_+$
and none for $\overline{\psi}_-$ and $\psi_+$.
Thus the path-integral measure contains a factor
fbegin{equation}
{\cal D}_A^{(0)}\Psi=\prod_{i=1}^{c_1}w\rm d}\psi_{-}^{(0)i}
w\rm d}\overline{\psi}_{+}^{(0)i},
\label{zeromme}
end{equation}
where $\psi_-^{(0)i}$ and $\overline{\psi}_+^{(0)i}$ are the zero modes,
which are complex conjugates of each other.
If $c_1$ is negative, the zero modes originate from $\overline{\psi}_-$ and $\psi_+$.
Observe that $c_1$ flips its sign under the worldsheet
orientation reversal $\Omega$.
It also flips under the $g_*$-conjugation
since $g_*\sigma_3 g_*^{-1}=-\sigma_3$.
Thus, the first Chern class flips its sign under ${\cal I}_A\Omega$ but
remains invariant under ${\cal I}_B\Omega$:
w
&&
{\cal I}_A\Omega:c_1\to -c_1,
\label{Ac1t}\\
&&
{\cal I}_B\Omega:c_1\to c_1.
\label{Bc1t}
bbnd{eqnarray}
Let us first examine ${\cal I}_B\Omega$,
which preserves the topology of the $U(1)$ gauge bundle by (\ref{Bc1t}).
By (\ref{Bpsit}),
${\cal I}_B\Omega$ sends the $(\psi_-,\overline{\psi}_+)$ zero modes
in the background $A$ to
the $(\overline{\psi}_+,\psi_-)$ zero modes
in the background $-\Omega^*A$.
Because of the Fermi statistics
$w\rm d}\overline{\psi}_{+}^{(0)i}
w\rm d}\psi_{-}^{(0)i}=-w\rm d}\psi_{-}^{(0)i}
w\rm d}\overline{\psi}_{+}^{(0)i}$,
the measure (\ref{zeromme}) is transformed as
fbegin{equation}
{\cal D}_A^{(0)}\Psi\longrightarrow
(-1)^{c_1}
{\cal D}_{-\Omega^*A}^{(0)}\Psi.
\label{anoma}
end{equation}
There is no extra sign from
the measure of the non-zero modes.
Since the field configurations $A$ and $-\Omega^*A$ are smoothly
connected,
there is no way to define the measure so that it is invariant under
${\cal I}_B\Omega$.
Thus, the parity ${\cal I}_B\Omega$ suffers from an anomaly.
Let us next consider ${\cal I}_A\Omega$.
By (\ref{Ac1t}), it changes the topology of the gauge bundle, except for
the trivial one $c_1=0$.
In the latter case there is no net fermionic zero mode and therefore
it is ${\cal I}_A\Omega$-invariant. 
For $c_1\ne 0$, one can choose the phase of the measure,
first for $c_1>0$ and then for $c_1<0$, so that
 it is invariant under ${\cal I}_A\Omega$,which sends $c_1$ to $-c_1$.
Thus, the parity ${\cal I}_A\Omega$ is anomaly-free.


\subsubsection{Cancellation of the anomaly}

We have seen that
fbegin{equation}
P_A:={\cal I}_A\Omega
end{equation}
is anomaly-free
but ${\cal I}_B\Omega$ suffers from a $\mathbb Z}_2$ anomaly

originating from the sign
$w\rm d}\overline{\psi}_+^{(0)}w\rm d}\psi_-^{(0)}
=-w\rm d}\psi_-^{(0)}w\rm d}\overline{\psi}_+^{(0)}$.
It is obviously cancelled by combination with the
transformation
$$
(-1)^{F_R}:(A,g,\Psi_-,\Psi_+)\to(A,g,-\Psi_-,\Psi_+).
$$
In other words, $(-1)^{F_R}$ has the same anomaly (\ref{anoma}) as
${\cal I}_B\Omega$.
Thus,
fbegin{equation}
P_B:=(-1)^{F_R}{\cal I}_B\Omega
end{equation}
is an anomaly-free parity symmetry of the system.

%\eeq
%which is the rotation by angle $\pi \ell/(k+2)$.
%It is of order 2 in the GSO projected theory

\subsubsection{Action on the supercurrents}

We determine how the parity symmetries transform the  supercurrents of the
system.
Let us start with $P_A:(A,g,\Psi)\to\Omega(A,g^{-1},\Psi)$,
which acts in the following way
$\psi_{\pm}(x)\to \psi_{\mp}(\widetilde{x})$,
$D_-gg^{-1}(x)\to D_+g^{-1}g(\widetilde{x})=-g^{-1}D_+g(\widetilde{x})$,
and
$g^{-1}D_+g(x)\to gD_-g^{-1}(\widetilde{x})=-D_-gg^{-1}(\widetilde{x})$.
It follows that $P_A$ transforms the currents as
w
&&G(x)\to \overline{\widetilde{G}}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\overline{G}(x)\to \widetilde{G}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
J(x)\to -\widetilde{J}(\widetilde{x})
\nonumber\\
&& \widetilde{G}(x)\to \overline{G}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\overline{\widetilde{G}}(x)\to G(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\widetilde{J}(x)\to -J(\widetilde{x})
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
and therefore $P_A$ is an A-parity.
One may also consider the combination
fbegin{equation}
P_A^{\alpha,\beta}:=\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha F_V-i\beta F_A}P_A.
end{equation}
This is an ${\rm A}_{\alpha,\beta}$-parity of the system.
It preserves an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry if $\beta\in \pi\mathbb Z}$.
Note that $a^{\ell}P_A=P_A^{{\pi\ell\over 2},-{\pi\ell\over 2}}$
and $(-1)^Fa^{\ell}P_A=P_A^{{\pi\ell\over 2},-{\pi(\ell-2)\over 2}}$
preserve an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry if $\ell$ is even,
while they are $\widetilde{A}$-parities if $\ell$ is odd.

%Among them, $a^{2m}P_A$ and $(-1)^Fa^{2m}P_A$ preserve
%an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry while
%$a^{2m+1}P_A$ and $(-1)^Fa^{2m+1}P_A$
%are $\widetilde{A}$-parities.

%parity $P_A^{\ell}=a_{\ell}\circ P_A$ does the same except that the first
%two of (\ref{PAtG}) is modified as $\tG(x)\to (-1)^{\ell}\bG(\Omega x),
%\btG(x)\to (-1)^{\ell} G(\Omega x)$. One can also consider $(-1)^FP_A$,
%where $(-1)^F$ flips the sign of the supercurrents but keeps the sign of
%the R-currents. In the GSO-projected theory, however, $(-1)^F$ is a gauge
%symmetry and there is no difference between $P_A$ and $(-1)^FP_A$.


We next consider $P_B=
(-1)^{F_R}\circ {\rm ad} g_*^{-1}\circ P_A$.
Note that ${\rm ad}g_*^{-1}$ exchanges $G\leftrightarrow\overline{G}$,
$\widetilde{G}\leftrightarrow \overline{\widetilde{G}}$, $J\leftrightarrow -J$, and
$\widetilde{J}\leftrightarrow -\widetilde{J}$. Thus $P_B$ transforms the currents as
w
&&G(x)\to -\widetilde{G}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\overline{G}(x)\to -\overline{\widetilde{G}}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
J(x)\to \widetilde{J}(\widetilde{x})
\nonumber\\
&& \widetilde{G}(x)\to G(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\overline{\widetilde{G}}(x)\to \overline{G}(\widetilde{x}),\,\,\,
\widetilde{J}(x)\to J(\widetilde{x}).
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
Thus, $P_B$ is a $\widetilde{\rm B}$-parity.
It can also be modified by the R-symmetry:
fbegin{equation}
P_B^{\alpha,\beta}
:=\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha F_V-i\beta F_A}P_B.
end{equation}
This is a ${\rm B}_{\alpha+{\pi\over 2},\beta-{\pi\over 2}}$-parity
of the system. It preserves an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry if
$\alpha+{\pi\over 2}\in\pi\mathbb Z}$.
Note that $a^{\ell}P_B=P_B^{{\pi\ell\over 2},-{\pi\ell\over 2}}$
and $(-1)^Fa^{\ell}P_B=P_B^{{\pi\ell\over 2},-{\pi(\ell-2)\over 2}}$
preserve an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry if $\ell$ is odd,
while they are $\widetilde{B}$-parities if $\ell$ is even.

%an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry while
%$a^{2m}P_A$ and $(-1)^Fa^{2m}P_A$
%are $\widetilde{B}$-parities.


%The transformation by
%$P_B^{\ell}=a_{\ell}\circ P_B$ is the same except that the first two of
%(\ref{PBtG}) are modified as
%$\tG(x)\to -(-1)^{\ell}G(\Omega x)$,
%$\btG(x)\to -(-1)^{\ell}\bG(\Omega x)$.
%Combination with $(-1)^F$ flips the sign of the supercurrents
%(although it does not change anything in GSO projected theory).


%If we look at these results, we find the following:\\
%$\bullet$ {\it $P_A^{\ell}$ or $(-1)^FP_A^{\ell}$
%is an A-parity if $\ell$ is even
%but it is an $\widetilde{A}$-parity if $\ell$ is odd.}\\
%$\bullet$ {\it $P_B^{\ell}$ or $(-1)^FP_B^{\ell}$
%is a B-parity if $\ell$ is odd
%but it is a $\widetilde{B}$-parity if $\ell$ is even.}


\subsubsection{The square of the parity}

In order to determine the sector to which the crosscap states
belong, we compute
the square of the above parities.

The basic A-parity $P_A={\cal I}_A\Omega$ is clearly
involutive, $P_A^2:(A,g,\Psi)\to \Omega(A,g^{-1},\Psi)
\to \Omega^2(A,(g^{-1})^{-1},\Psi)=(A,g,\Psi)$.
To find the square of the modified parities $P_A^{\alpha,\beta}$,
we note that conjugation by $P_A$ flips the sign of
$F_V=J_0+\widetilde{J}_0$, while
$F_A=-J_0+\widetilde{J}_0$ is invariant,
thus we see that
$$
(P_A^{\alpha,\beta})^2=\,{\rm e}^{-2i\beta F_A}.
$$
Since $\,{\rm e}^{-2i\beta F_A}$ is gauge-equivalent to
the fermion phase rotation $\psi_{\pm}\to\,{\rm e}^{-2i\beta}\psi_{\pm}$,
$P_A^{\alpha,\beta}$ is involutive as long as $\beta\in\pi \mathbb Z}$, that is,
if and only if it preserves an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry.
Namely, $|\Scr{C}_{P_A^{\alpha,\beta}}\rangle$ belongs to
 the RR-sector if and only if
$P_A^{\alpha,\beta}$ is supersymmetric.
Both $a^{\ell}P_A$ and $(-1)^Fa^{\ell}P_A$
square to $(-1)^{\ell F}$, and  their crosscaps therefore
belong to the RR (resp.~NSNS) sector if $\ell$ is even (resp.~odd),




Let us compute the square of $P_B=(-1)^{F_R}{\mathcal I}_B\Omega$.
The transformation ${\mathcal I}_B\Omega$ is involutive since
$g_*^2=-1$ is the central element of $SU(2)$.
On the other hand, $(-1)^{F_R}$ is transformed to $(-1)^{F_L}$
under conjugation by ${\mathcal I}_B\Omega$.
Thus, we find $P_B^2=(-1)^F$.
To find the square of $P_B^{\alpha,\beta}$, we note that
conjugation by $P_B$ keeps $F_V$ invariant but
flips the sign of $F_A$.
Thus, we see that
$$
(P_B^{\alpha,\beta})^2=\,{\rm e}^{-2i\alpha F_V}(-1)^F.
$$
$\,{\rm e}^{-2i\alpha F_V}$ is the fermion phase rotation
$\psi_{\pm}\to\,{\rm e}^{\mp 2i\alpha}\psi_{\pm}$ combined with the
axial rotation by $h_{-2\alpha}$.
This cancels $(-1)^F$ if and only if $2\alpha\in \pi(k+2)\mathbb Z}$ as well as
$2\alpha\in\pi(2\mathbb Z}+1)$.
This is possible only if $k$ is odd, in which case
one may take $\alpha=\pi{k+2\over 2}$.
Thus, if $k$ is even, none of the Parities $P_B^{\alpha,\beta}$ is involutive.
If $k$ is odd, $P_B^{\pi(k+2)/2,\beta}$ is involutive.
Both of $a^{\ell}P_B$ and $(-1)^Fa^{\ell}P_B$
square to $\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i \ell F_V}(-1)^F=(-1)^{(\ell+1)F}a^{2\ell}$
and hence the crosscap states belong to the sector twisted by this symmetry.
If $k$ is odd, $a^{k+2}P_B$ and $(-1)^Fa^{k+2}P_B$
are involutive.



\subsubsection{Geometric picture}
\label{subsub:geoac}

The above parities yield transformations of the
disc $z\mapsto P^{-1}zP$, which are
isometries of the metric (\ref{disc}).
The A-parities act on the coordinate $z$ as
fbegin{equation}
P_A^{\alpha,\beta}:z\to \,{\rm e}^{i {2\alpha\over k+2}}\overline{z},
\label{PAdisk}
end{equation}
which is the reflection with respect to
the line $\,{\rm e}^{i{\alpha\over k+2}}{\mathbb R}$.
The action of the B-parities are
fbegin{equation}
P_B^{\alpha,\beta}:z\to \,{\rm e}^{i {2\alpha\over k+2}}z,
\label{PBdisk}
end{equation}
which are rotations of the disc. The involutive parity
$P_B^{\pi(k+2)/2,\beta}$ acts on the disc as a rotation by $\pi$,
or an inversion $z\to -z$.



\subsection{Description in the operator formalism}\label{sub:DOF}

In this subsection,
we see how the parity symmetries act on the states.










\subsubsection{The spectrum}

The space of states of the theory are the
gauge invariant states in the parent theory, $SU(2)$ WZW model plus
the free Dirac fermion system, modulo the large gauge transformations.
We formulate the system on a circle of radius $2\pi$.
The space of states of the WZW model is
$$
{\mathcal H}^{G,k}=\bigoplus_{j\in {\rm P}_k}\widehat{V}_j\otimes\widehat{V}_j,
$$
where $\widehat{V}_j$ is the spin $j$ representation of the
$SU(2)$ current algebra at level $k$
and  ${\rm P}_k=\{0,{1\over 2},1,...,{k\over 2}\}$ is the set of integrable spins
at level $k$.
The space of states of the Dirac fermion system
is composed of the Fock space, which depends on the choice of
periodicity along the circle.
For the boundary condition
$\psi_-(\sigma+2\pi)=\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i a}\psi_-(\sigma)$
and $\psi_+(\sigma+2\pi)=\,{\rm e}^{-2\pi i \widetilde{a}}\psi_+(\sigma)$,
the space of states is
$$
{\mathcal H}^f_{a,\widetilde{a}}={\mathcal F}_a\otimes {\mathcal F}_{\widetilde{a}}.
$$
Here ${\mathcal F}_a$ is the Fock space
for the fermion oscillator algebra
$\{\psi_{r_1},\psi_{r_2}\}=\{\overline{\psi}_{r_1'},\overline{\psi}_{r'_2}\}=0$,
$\{\psi_r,\overline{\psi}_{r'}\}=\delta_{r+r',0}$ where,
$r\in \mathbb Z}+a$ and $r'\in\mathbb Z}-a$.
It is built on the vacuum state $|0\rangle_a$,
which is annihilated by $\psi_r$ ($r\geq 0$)
and $\overline{\psi}_{r'}$ ($r'>0$).
The fermion number operator is given by
fbegin{equation}
J_0^f=\sum_{r\in \mathbb Z}+a}:\!\overline{\psi}_{-r}\psi_r\!:+a-[a]-{1\over 2}.
\label{J0f}
end{equation}
Here, $a=0$ and $a={1\over 2}$ are the R  and
NS  sectors respectively.
The space of states of the total parent theory is the tensor product
$$
{\mathcal H}^{\rm parent}_{a,\widetilde{a}}
={\mathcal H}^{G,k}\otimes {\mathcal H}^f_{a,\widetilde{a}}
=
\bigoplus_{j\in {\rm P}_k}
\bigoplus_{
s\in 2\mathbb Z}+2a-1
\atop
\widetilde{s}\in 2\mathbb Z}+2\widetilde{a}-1}
\widehat{V}_j\otimes {\mathcal F}_a|_{s}
\otimes
\widehat{V}_j\otimes {\mathcal F}_{\widetilde{a}}|_{\widetilde{s}},
$$
where ${\mathcal F}_{a}|_s$ is the subspace of 
${\mathcal F}_{a}$ in which $J_0^f=s/2$ ($s$ takes values
in $2(\mathbb Z}+(a-1/2))$ by (\ref{J0f})).
The gauge invariant states are those obeying
the condition
w
&&J_n^H=\widetilde{J}_n^H=0,\quad n\geq 1,
\nonumber\\
&&J_0^H+\widetilde{J}_0^H+2(a+\widetilde{a})=0,
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
where $J_n^H=J_n^3-2J_n^f$ and $\widetilde{J}^H_n=\widetilde{J}_n^3-2\widetilde{J}_n^f$
according to (\ref{JH}). $J_n^H$ and $\widetilde{J}_n^H$ generate the $U(1)$
current algebra at level $k+2$.
Let us denote by $B_{j,n,s}$
the subspace of $\widehat{V}_j\otimes {\mathcal F}_a|_{s}$ in which
$J^H_n=0$ ($n\geq 1$) and $J^H_0=-n$, so that
$$
\widehat{V}_j^{G,k}\otimes {\mathcal F}_a|_{s}=\bigoplus_{n\in 2\mathbb Z}+2j+s}B_{j,n,s}
\otimes \widehat{V}_{-n}^{H,k+2}.
$$
Then, the space of gauge invariant states is
$$
\left({\mathcal H}^{\rm parent}_{a,\widetilde{a}}\right)^{H-{\rm inv}}
=\bigoplus_{j\in {\rm P}_k}
\bigoplus_{
s\in 2\mathbb Z}+2a-1
\atop
\widetilde{s}\in 2\mathbb Z}+2\widetilde{a}-1}
\bigoplus_{n\in 2\mathbb Z}+2j+s}B_{j,n,s}\otimes
B_{j,-n+2(a+\widetilde{a}),\widetilde{s}}.
$$
The topology of the gauge group $\pi_1(H)=\pi_1(U(1))=\mathbb Z}$
allows  large gauge
transformations, which act on the labels as
$(j,n,s,\tilde{s})\to ({k\over 2}-j,n\pm(k+2),s\pm 2,\tilde{s}\mp 2)
\to (j,n\pm 2(k+2),s\pm 4,\tilde{s}\mp 4)\to\cdots$.
This induces the so-called ``field identification'' \cite{FIGep,MS,FIH}.
Namely, the space of states of our gauge system is given by
fbegin{equation}
{\cal H}_{a,\widetilde{a}}=\bigoplus_{(j,n,s,\tilde{s})\in \widetilde{\rm M}_k(a,\widetilde{a})}
B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n+2(a+\widetilde{a}),\widetilde{s}}
end{equation}
where $\widetilde{\rm M}_k(a,\widetilde{a})$ is the infinite set
$$
\widetilde{\rm M}_k(a,\widetilde{a})=\left\{(j,n,s,\tilde{s}) \Biggl|
\begin{array}{l}
j\in {\rm P}_k,\quad
2j-s+n\,\,{\rm even}\\
s\in 2\mathbb Z}+2a-1,\,\,
\widetilde{s}\in 2\mathbb Z}+2\widetilde{a}-1
\end{array}
\right\}\Bigl/\pi_1(H).
$$
The R-currents (\ref{Rright}) and (\ref{Rleft}) are
expressed as
$$
J_n={1\over k+2}J_n^H+J_n^f,
\,\,\,\,
\widetilde{J}_n=-{1\over k+2}\widetilde{J}_n^H-\widetilde{J}_n^f,
$$
and hence the R-charges ($(J_0,\widetilde{J}_0)$-eigenvalues) are given by
fbegin{equation}
(q,\widetilde{q})=\left(-{n\over k+2}+{s\over 2},
{\widetilde{n}\over k+2}-{\widetilde{s}\over 2}\right)
\,\,\,\,
\mbox{on $B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,\widetilde{n},\widetilde{s}}$}.
end{equation}
The supercharges (\ref{Gexpr1})-(\ref{Gexpr4})
are expressed, after the standard shift $k\to k+2$, as
w
&&\overline{G}_{r'}=\sqrt{2\over k+2}\sum_{n\in\mathbb Z}}
\overline{\psi}_{r'-n}J_n^+,
\quad
G_r=\sqrt{2\over k+2}\sum_{n\in\mathbb Z}}
\psi_{r-n}J_n^-,
\quad (r,-r'\in \mathbb Z}+a),
\nonumber\\
&&\overline{\widetilde{G}}_{\widetilde{r}}=\sqrt{2\over k+2}\sum_{n\in\mathbb Z}}
\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}-n}\widetilde{J}_n^-,
\quad
\widetilde{G}_{\widetilde{r}'}=\sqrt{2\over k+2}\sum_{n\in\mathbb Z}}
\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}'-n}\widetilde{J}_n^+,
\quad (\widetilde{r},-\widetilde{r}'\in \mathbb Z}+\widetilde{a}).
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
{\bf Remark.}
We regard the $(a,\widetilde{a})$ sector to be
the sector in which the fields obey the boundary condition
w
&&\Phi(\sigma)=U_{a,\widetilde{a}}^{-1}\Phi(\sigma+2\pi)U_{a,\widetilde{a}},
\nonumber\\
&&\quad U_{a,\widetilde{a}}:=\,{\rm e}^{-2\pi i(aJ_0+\widetilde{a}\widetilde{J}_0)}
=\,{\rm e}^{-2\pi i (a-{1\over 2})J_0-2\pi i(\widetilde{a}+{1\over 2})\widetilde{J}_0}(-1)^F.
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
Note that $(-1)^F:=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i (-J_0+\widetilde{J}_0)}$ is the mod 2 fermion number
(\ref{mod2F}).
In particular the standard NSNS sector is
$(a,\widetilde{a})=({1\over 2},-{1\over 2})$, and it indeed includes
the $SL(2,{\mathbb C})$-invariant
ground state $[|0;0\rangle\otimes |0\rangle_{1\over 2}]\otimes
[|0;0\rangle\otimes |0\rangle_{-{1\over 2}}]\in B_{0,0,0}\otimes B_{0,0,0}
\subset {\mathcal H}_{{1\over 2},-{1\over 2}}$.
The $(a,\widetilde{a})$ sector is the spectral flow \cite{SchSei}
from this
by $(a-{1\over 2},\widetilde{a}+{1\over 2})$.
Because of the periodicity of the R-symmetries, we have the
identifications
$(a,\widetilde{a})\equiv (a+(k+2),\widetilde{a})\equiv
(a,\widetilde{a}+(k+2))\equiv (a+1,\widetilde{a}-1)$.




\subsubsection*{\it Chiral primaries}



The local operators of the system can be mapped one-to-one to
the states in the NSNS sector ($a=-\widetilde{a}={1\over 2}$).
Chiral primary fields correspond to those obeying the conditions
$\overline{G}_{-{1\over 2}}=\overline{\widetilde{G}}_{-{1\over 2}}=0$ and $G_{{1\over 2}}=\widetilde{G}_{{1\over 2}}=0$.
One can show that they are given by
$$
|j\rangle^{}_{\it cc}=\Bigl[|j,j\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm NS}\Bigr]
\otimes
\Bigl[|j,-j\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm NS}\Bigr],
\,\,\,\,
j=0,{1\over 2},1,\ldots,{k\over 2},
$$
which belongs to $B_{j,-2j,0}\otimes B_{j,2j,0}$. 
The corresponding chiral primary ${\mathcal O}_j$
has R-charges $(q,\widetilde{q})=({2j\over k+2},{2j\over k+2})$.
There are also antichiral primaries $\overline{\mathcal O}_j$
corresponding to
$|j\rangle^{}_{\it aa}=[|j,-j\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm NS}]
\otimes
[|j,j\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm NS}]$ in
$B_{j,2j,0}\otimes B_{j,-2j,0}$
with charge $(q,\widetilde{q})=(-{2j\over k+2},-{2j\over k+2})$.
There are no twisted (anti)chiral primaries, except for the identity operator. 


\subsubsection*{\it Supersymmetric ground states}

The supersymmetry of the sector with $a,\widetilde{a}\in \mathbb Z}$ is
generated by $G_0,\overline{G}_0,\widetilde{G}_0,\overline{\widetilde{G}}_0$. We would like to find
the supersymmetric ground states, namely the states
annihilated by all of $G_0,\overline{G}_0,\widetilde{G}_0,\overline{\widetilde{G}}_0$.


We start with the RR sector ($a=\widetilde{a}=0$).
The supersymmetric ground states are
$$
|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}
=\Bigl[|j;j\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr]
\otimes
\Bigl[|j;-j\rangle\otimes \overline{\psi}_0|0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr],
\,\,\,\,
j=0,{1\over 2},1,\ldots,{k\over 2},
$$
where $|0\rangle_{\rm R}$ is the vacuum state
$|0\rangle_0\in {\mathcal F}_0$, which is
annihilated by $\psi_0$ and has $J_0^f=-1/2$.
The state $|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}$
belongs to $B_{j,-(2j+1),-1}\otimes B_{j,2j+1,1}$ and has R-charges
$(q,\widetilde{q})=({2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2},{2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2})$.
Another representation of the same state (up to a phase) is
$$
|j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}=
\Bigl[|{k\over 2}-j;-{k\over 2}+j\rangle\otimes \overline{\psi}_0
|0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr]
\otimes \Bigl[|{k\over 2}-j;{k\over 2}-j\rangle
\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr],
$$
which belongs to
$B_{{k\over 2}-j,(k+2)-(2j+1),1}\otimes B_{{k\over 2}-j,-(k+2)+(2j+1),-1}$.
The state $|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\propto |j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}$
 corresponds to the chiral primary field
${\mathcal O}_j$.


We next consider the sectors with
twisted boundary conditions $(a,\widetilde{a})\not\equiv (0,0)$.
(There are $k+1$ such sectors labelled by $a+\widetilde{a}\in\{1,2,\ldots,k+1\}$.)
For each such sector, there is a unique supersymmetric ground state
$$
|{\rm G}\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}
=\Bigl[|j_{*};j_{*}\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr]
\otimes
\Bigl[|j_{*};j_{*}\rangle\otimes |0\rangle^{}_{\rm R}\Bigr]
\in
B_{j_{*},-2j_{*}-1,-1}\otimes
B_{j_{*},-2j_{*}-1,-1},
$$
where $j_*\in {\rm P}_k$ is defined by 
$2j_{*}+1\equiv -a-\widetilde{a}$ mod $(k+2)$.
It has R-charge
$(q,\widetilde{q})=({2j_*+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2},-{2j_*+1\over k+2}+{1\over 2})$.

The above results are consistent with the equivariant Witten indices.
Let us consider the partition function on the torus
$(x,y)\equiv (x+1,y)\equiv (x,y+1)$
with the (twisted) boundary condition $\Phi(x,y)=\Phi(x+1,y)
=U_{a,\widetilde{a}}^{-1}\Phi(x,y+1)U_{a,\widetilde{a}}$.
There is a supersymmetry as long as $a,\widetilde{a}\in\mathbb Z}$,
and the partition function is regarded as the Witten index.
If we consider $x$ as the space and $y$ as the time coordinate,
this can be regarded as the trace over the RR sector of the 
operator $U_{a,\widetilde{a}}(-1)^F\,{\rm e}^{-\beta H}$.
If, on the other hand, we consider $x$ as the time and $y$ as the space
coordinate, the partition function is identified as the
trace over the $(a,\widetilde{a})$-sector of the operator
$(-1)^F\,{\rm e}^{-\beta' H}$.
We thus find the identity
$$
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i (aJ_0+\widetilde{a}\widetilde{J}_0)}(-1)^F\,{\rm e}^{-\beta H}
=\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{a,\widetilde{a}}}\!\!
(-1)^F\,{\rm e}^{-\beta' H}.
$$
The left hand side is the equivariant Witten index and can be computed,
using our knowledge of the supersymmetric ground states
in the RR sector, as
w
{\rm LHS}&=&
\sum_{j\in{\rm P}_k}\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i (a-{1\over 2})q_j+2\pi i (\widetilde{a}+{1\over 2})\widetilde{q}_j}
=\sum_{2j=0,1,...,k}\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i(a+\widetilde{a})({2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2})}
\nonumber\\
&=&
-\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i(a+\widetilde{a})}=\pm 1
\qquad \mbox{if $a+\widetilde{a} \not\equiv 0$ mod $(k+2)$}.
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
On the other hand, the right hand side is the ordinary Witten index
for the system twisted by $U_{a,\widetilde{a}}$, which computes the number of bosonic
supersymmetric ground states minus the number of fermionic ones.
That it is equal to LHS=$\pm 1$ if $a+\widetilde{a} \not\equiv 0$
 is consistent with the above conclusion
 that there is a unique supersymmetric ground states in
${\mathcal H}_{a,\widetilde{a}}$ with $a+\widetilde{a} \not\equiv 0$.




\subsubsection{The parity action}

Let us now see how  parity acts on the states.
We will also compute the twisted partition function for the
NSNS and RR sectors.





\subsubsection*{\it A-Parity}

We start with the basic parity symmetry $P_A={\cal I}_A\Omega$.
Since the space of states is basically
the subspace of the tensor product
${\mathcal H}^{G,k}\otimes {\mathcal H}_{a,\widetilde{a}}^f$,
we separate the discussion into bosonic and fermionic sectors.
The action on the bosonic part is determined in \cite{BH1}:
fbegin{equation}
u_b\otimes \widetilde{v_b}\in \widehat{V}_j\otimes\widehat{V}_j
\,\,\longmapsto\,\,
(-1)^{2j} v_b\otimes \widetilde{u_b}\in \widehat{V}_j\otimes\widehat{V}_j.
end{equation}
For the fermionic sector it exchanges the periodicity parameter $a$, $\widetilde{a}$
of the left and right movers, ${\mathcal H}^f_{a,\widetilde{a}}\to
{\mathcal H}_{\widetilde{a},a}^f$, mapping
the oscillators as
fbegin{equation}
\psi_r,\,\,\overline{\psi}_{r'},\,\,
\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}},\,\,\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}'}
\longrightarrow
\widetilde{\psi}_r,\,\,\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{r'},\,\,
\psi_{\widetilde{r}},\,\,\overline{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}'},
end{equation}
where $r,-r'\in\mathbb Z}+a$ and $\widetilde{r},-\widetilde{r}'\in\mathbb Z}+\widetilde{a}$.
It follows  that the ground state
$|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}=|0\rangle_a\otimes |0\rangle_{\widetilde{a}}$
(annihilated by $\psi_{r\geq 0}$, $\overline{\psi}_{r'>0}$,
$\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}\geq 0}$ and $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}'>0}$)
is mapped
to the ground state $|0\rangle_{\widetilde{a},a}$
(annihilated by $\psi_{\widetilde{r}\geq 0}$, $\overline{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}'>0}$,
$\widetilde{\psi}_{r\geq 0}$ and $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{r'>0}$)
up to a phase,
$|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}\mapsto \epsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}|0\rangle_{\widetilde{a},a}$.
More general states are mapped as
fbegin{equation}
{\mathcal O}_1\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_2}
|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}\,\,
\longmapsto\,\,
\epsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}
\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_1}{\mathcal O}_2
|0\rangle_{\widetilde{a},a}
=
\epsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}(-1)^{|{\mathcal O}_1||{\mathcal O}_2|}
{\mathcal O}_2\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_1}
|0\rangle_{\widetilde{a},a}.
end{equation}
Here, ${\mathcal O}_i$ are polynomials of the fermion oscillators
$\psi_{\bullet}$, $\overline{\psi}_{\bullet}$,
and $\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_i}$ are
the ones where $\psi_{\bullet}$, $\overline{\psi}_{\bullet}$ 
are replaced by $\widetilde{\psi}_{\bullet}$, $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\bullet}$.
$|{\mathcal O}_i|$ is the fermion number of ${\mathcal O}_i$.
Thus, we find that the states of the combined system are mapped as
follows
w
P_A&:&u_a\otimes \widetilde{v_b}\otimes
{\mathcal O}_1\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_2}|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}
\in B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n+2(a+\widetilde{a}),\widetilde{s}}
\nonumber\\
&&\,\,\longmapsto\,\,
\epsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}(-1)^{2j+|{\mathcal O}_1||{\mathcal O}_2|}
v_b\otimes\widetilde{u_b}\otimes
{\mathcal O}_2\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_1}
|0\rangle_{\widetilde{a},a}
\in B_{j,-n+2(a+\widetilde{a}),\widetilde{s}}\otimes B_{j,n,s},\quad
\label{PAaction}
bbnd{eqnarray}
where
$$
|{\mathcal O}_1|={s\over 2}-(a-[a]-{1\over 2}),
\quad
|{\mathcal O}_2|={\widetilde{s}\over 2}-(\widetilde{a}-[\widetilde{a}]-{1\over 2}).
$$
One can check that this action is compatible with the field identification.
Let us show this for the action on the RR ground states,
$|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}=|j;j\rangle\otimes |j;-j\rangle\otimes
\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}$
$\propto$
$|j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}
=|{k\over 2}-j;-({k\over 2}-j)\rangle\otimes
|{k\over 2}-j;{k\over 2}-j\rangle\otimes
\overline{\psi}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}$
Using (\ref{PAaction}), we find that they are mapped as
$$
|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\mapsto 
\epsilon_{0,0}(-1)^{2j}|{k\over 2}-j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}},
\quad
|j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}\mapsto \epsilon_{0,0}(-1)^{k-2j}
|{k\over 2}-j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}.
$$
This is consistent with the field identification
$|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\propto |j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}$, provided
that
fbegin{equation}
|{k\over 4}\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}=\pm |{k\over 4}\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}},
\label{sign}
end{equation}
which is non-vacuous only if $k$ is even.
This also shows that $P_A$ is involutive only if $\epsilon_{0,0}$
is $1$ or $-1$.

Let us compute the twisted partition function
for the NSNS and RR sectors.
The subspaces $B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n,\widetilde{s}}$
 that contribute to it are such that
it is equivalent to $B_{j,-n,\widetilde{s}}\otimes B_{j,n,s}$
up to field identification.
This is so for
$B_{j,0,s}\otimes B_{j,0,s}$
and $B_{{k\over 4},-{k+2\over 2},s}\otimes B_{{k\over 4},{k+2\over 2},s+2}$
($k$ even).
It is then straightforward to compute the partition functions.
We present the result for the more general parity
$P_A^{\alpha,\beta}=\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha F_V-i\beta F_A}P_A$.
For the NSNS sector it is
w
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm NSNS}}\!\!
(P_A^{\alpha,\beta}q^H)
&=&\epsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}\sum_{2j,s\,{\rm even}}
(-1)^{s\over 2}\,{\rm e}^{i\beta s}{\rm ch}_{j,0,s}(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&=&\epsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}
\sum_{2j\,{\rm even}}(\chi_{j,0,0}
-\chi_{j,0,2})(2\tau,\mbox{$\beta\over\pi$}),
bbnd{eqnarray}
and for the RR sector
w
\lefteqn{\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
(P_A^{\alpha,\beta}q^H)}\nonumber\\
&=&-\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\sum_{2j,s\,{\rm odd}}
(-1)^{s+1\over 2}\,{\rm e}^{i\beta s}{\rm ch}_{j,o,s}(2\tau)
\pm \epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}(-1)^{k\over 2}\sum_{s\,{\rm odd}}
(-1)^{s+1\over 2}\,{\rm e}^{2i\beta {s+1\over 2}}
{\rm ch}_{{k\over 2},-{k+2\over 2},s}(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&=&
-\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\sum_{2j\,{\rm odd}}(\chi_{j,0,-1}
-\chi_{j,0,1})(2\tau,\mbox{$\beta\over\pi$})
\pm\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}(-1)^{k\over 2}
(\chi_{{k\over 2},-{k+2\over 2},-1}
-\chi_{{k\over 2},-{k+2\over 2},1})(2\tau,\mbox{$\beta\over\pi$}).
\nonumber\\
\label{partPARR}
bbnd{eqnarray}
In the above expressions, ${\rm ch}_{j,n,s}$ is the character
fbegin{equation}
{\rm ch}_{j,n,s}(\tau)
=\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{B_{j,n,s}}\!\!
q^{L_0-{c\over 24}},
\label{defcha}
end{equation}
and $\chi_{j,n,s}$, for $s\in \mathbb Z}/4\mathbb Z}$, is
$$
\chi_{j,n,s}(\tau,u)
=\sum_{p\in\mathbb Z}}\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{B_{j,n,s+4p}}\!\!
q^{L_0-{c\over 24}}\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i J_0 u}
=\sum_{p\in\mathbb Z}}\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i u(-{n\over k+2}+{s+4p\over 2})}
{\rm ch}_{j,n,s+4p}(\tau),
$$
The sign $\pm$ of the second term on
the right hand side of (\ref{partPARR}) is
the same as the one that appears in the
Field Identification (\ref{sign}).

The special cases are the ones with $(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_A$-twists
($\nu=0,1$):
w
&&
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm NSNS}}\!\!
((-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_Aq^H)
=\epsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}\sum_{2j\,{\rm even}}
(\chi_{j,0,0}-(-1)^{\ell}\chi_{j,0,2})(2\tau),
\label{pfNSNS1}\\
&&
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
((-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_Aq^H)
=-\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\ell\over 2}(-1)^{\nu}\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\sum_{2j\,{\rm odd}}(\chi_{j,0,-1}
-(-1)^{\ell}\chi_{j,0,1})(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&&\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad
\pm\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\delta^{(2)}_k(-1)^{k\over 2}
(\chi_{{k\over 4},-{k+2\over 2},-1}
-(-1)^{\ell}\chi_{{k\over 4},-{k+2\over 2},1})(2\tau).
\label{pfRR1}
bbnd{eqnarray}
We recall that $(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_A$
with even $\ell$ preserves an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry and the
twisted partition function in the RR-sector can be regarded as
the Witten index.
Indeed, since $\chi_{j,n,-1}-\chi_{j,n,1}=\pm\delta_{n,\mp(2j+1)}$,
we find
fbegin{equation}
I_{a^{\rm even}P_A}=
\pm\epsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}(-1)^{k\over 2}\delta^{(2)}_k.
\label{Wtind1}
end{equation}
For odd $\ell$, $(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_A$ breaks all supersymmetry
and the partition function is indeed a non-trivial function
of $\tau$.




\subsubsection*{\it B-Parity}



We next consider B-parity $P_B=(-1)^{F_R}{\cal I}_B\Omega$, which is
the same as $P_A$ followed by $(-1)^{J_0^f}{\rm ad}g_*^{-1}$.
The action of ${\rm ad}g_*^{-1}$ on the bosonic sector
is the usual one, $u_b\otimes \widetilde{v_b}\mapsto
g_*u_b\otimes \widetilde{g_*v_b}$,
where $g_*$ acts on the ground states of $\widehat{V}_j$ as
$g_*|j;m\rangle=i^{2j}|j;-m\rangle$ \cite{BH1}.
Let us next see how ${\rm ad}g_*^{-1}$ acts on the fermionic sector.
Since it exchanges $\psi_{\pm}$ and $\overline{\psi}_{\pm}$,
it flips the sign of the periodicity parameter $(a,\widetilde{a})$,
${\mathcal H}_{a,\widetilde{a}}^f\to{\mathcal H}_{-a,-\widetilde{a}}^f$, and maps
the oscillators as
fbegin{equation}
{\rm ad}g_*^{-1}\,:\,\psi_r,\,\,\overline{\psi}_{r'},\,\,
\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}},\,\,\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}'}
\longrightarrow
\overline{\psi}_r,\,\,\psi_{r'},\,\,
\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}},\,\,\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}'}.
end{equation}
It follows from this that the ground state
$|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}$ (annihilated by $\psi_{r\geq 0}$,
$\overline{\psi}_{r'>0}$, $\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}\geq 0}$ and $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}'>0}$)
is mapped to the ground state
$|0\rangle_{-a,-\widetilde{a}}'$ (annihilated by $\psi_{r'\geq 0}$,
$\overline{\psi}_{r>0}$, $\widetilde{\psi}_{\widetilde{r}'\geq 0}$ and $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_{\widetilde{r}>0}$)
up to a phase, $|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}\mapsto\eta_{a,\widetilde{a}}|0\rangle'_{-a,-\widetilde{a}}$,
Note that one may set $|0\rangle_{-a,-\widetilde{a}}'=|0\rangle_{-a,-\widetilde{a}}$,
as long as $a,\widetilde{a}\not\in\mathbb Z}$.
If $a$ or $\widetilde{a}$ is an integer, they are not proportional to
each other. For example $|0\rangle_{0,0}$ is
annihilated by $\psi_0$, $\widetilde{\psi}_0$, while
$|0\rangle_{0,0}'$ is annihilated by $\overline{\psi}_0$, $\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_0$,
and therefore one may set
$|0\rangle_{0,0}'=\overline{\psi}_0\overline{\widetilde{\psi}_0}|0\rangle_{0,0}$.
More general states are mapped as
$$
{\rm ad}g_*^{-1}\,:\,
{\mathcal O}_1\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_2}|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}
\,\,\longmapsto\,\,
\eta_{a,\widetilde{a}}\overline{\mathcal O}_1\widetilde{\overline{\mathcal O}_2}
|0\rangle'_{a,\widetilde{a}}.
$$
Combining with the action of $P_A$ and $(-1)^{F_R}=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i J^f_0}$,
we find that $P_B=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i J^f_0}{\rm ad}g_*^{-1}P_A$ acts on the states as
w
P_B&:&
u_a\otimes \widetilde{v_b}\otimes
{\mathcal O}_1\widetilde{{\mathcal O}_2}|0\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}
\in B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n+2(a+\widetilde{a}),\widetilde{s}}%\,\,\longmapsto\,\,
\nonumber\\
&&\!\!\!\!\!\!\longmapsto\,
\varepsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}(-1)^{2j+|{\mathcal O}_1||{\mathcal O}_2|}
\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i{\widetilde{s}\over 2}}
g_*(v_b)\otimes \widetilde{g_*(u_b)}\otimes
\overline{\mathcal O}_2\widetilde{\overline{\mathcal O}_1}
|0\rangle_{-\widetilde{a},-a}'\in
B_{j,n-2(a+\widetilde{a}),-\widetilde{s}}\otimes B_{j,-n,-s},
\nonumber\\
\label{PBaction}
bbnd{eqnarray}
where $\varepsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}=\epsilon_{a,\widetilde{a}}\eta_{\widetilde{a},a}$.
Let us see if it is compatible with the field identification.
We examine it in the action on the RR ground states.
Using (\ref{PBaction}), we find the following $P_B$ action
w
&&|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}=|j;j\rangle\otimes |j;-j\rangle\otimes
\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}
\,\longmapsto\,
\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2}}|j;j\rangle\otimes |j;-j\rangle\otimes
\psi_0|0\rangle_{0,0}'=
\nonumber\\
&&\quad\qquad\quad\qquad\quad\qquad
=\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2}}|j;j\rangle\otimes |j;-j\rangle\otimes
\psi_0\overline{\psi}_0\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}
=\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2}}|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\nonumber\\[0.2cm]
&&|j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}
=|j';-j'\rangle\otimes
|j';j'\rangle\otimes
\overline{\psi}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}
\,\longmapsto\,
\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\over 2}|j';-j'\rangle\otimes
|j';j'\rangle\otimes
\widetilde{\psi}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}'=
\nonumber\\
&&\quad\qquad\quad\qquad\quad\qquad
=\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\over 2}|j';-j'\rangle\otimes
|j';j'\rangle\otimes
\widetilde{\psi}_0\overline{\psi}_0\overline{\widetilde{\psi}}_0|0\rangle_{0,0}
=-\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\over 2}|j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}},
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
where $j':={k\over 2}-j$.
We see that the action is compatible with the field identification
$|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\propto |j\rangle'_{{}_{\rm RR}}$.
Note that it would have been incompatible without the
$(-1)^{F_R}=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i J_0^f}$ factor. This corresponds to the
anomaly of ${\mathcal I}_B\Omega={\rm ad}g_*^{-1}P_A$ and its cancellation by
$(-1)^{F_R}$.

Let us now compute the twisted partition function in the NSNS and RR
sectors. A non-zero contribution comes from the subspaces
$B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n,-s}$.
The result is
w
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm NSNS}}\!\!
(P_B^{\alpha,\beta}q^H)
&=&\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}\sum_{2j+n,\,s\,{\rm even}}
\,{\rm e}^{-2i\alpha (-{n\over k+2}+{s\over 2})}{\rm ch}_{j,n,s}(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&=&\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}\sum_{2j+n\,{\rm even}\atop
s=0,2}\chi_{j,n,s}(2\tau,-\mbox{$\alpha\over\pi$}),
\\
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
(P_B^{\alpha,\beta}q^H)
&=&\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\sum_{2j+n,\,s\,{\rm odd}}
\,{\rm e}^{-2i\alpha (-{n\over k+2}+{s\over 2})}{\rm ch}_{j,n,s}(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&=&\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\sum_{2j+n\,{\rm odd}\atop
s=\pm 1}\chi_{j,n,s}(2\tau,-\mbox{$\alpha\over\pi$}),
bbnd{eqnarray}
where $\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}=\varepsilon_{0,0}\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2}}$.


Let us consider the special cases with $(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_B$-twists
($\nu=0,1$):
w
&&
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm NSNS}}\!\!
((-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_Bq^H)
=\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm NSNS}}\sum_{2j+n\,{\rm even}\atop s=0,2}
\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\ell({n\over k+2}-{s\over 2})}
\chi_{j,n,s}(2\tau)
\label{pfNSNS2}
\\
&&
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
((-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_Bq^H)
=\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\sum_{2j+n\,{\rm odd}\atop s=-1,1}
\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\ell({n\over k+2}-{s\over 2})}
\chi_{j,n,s}(2\tau)
\label{pfRR2}
bbnd{eqnarray}
$(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_B$
with odd $\ell$ preserves an ${\mathcal N}=2$ supersymmetry and the
twisted partition function in the RR-sector can be regarded as
the Witten index.
Indeed, it is just a number
w
I_{a^{\ell}P_B}&=&\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}
\sum_{j\in{\rm P}_k}\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\ell({2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2})}
=\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i{\ell\over 2}}
(z+z^2+\cdots+z^{k+1})|_{z=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i\ell/(k+2)}}
\nonumber
\\
&=&
\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i{\ell\over 2}}{z-z^{k+2}\over 1-z}
=
i\varepsilon_{{}_{\rm RR}}\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\ell\over 2}}
\cot\left[{\pi \ell\over 2(k+2)}\right],
\quad\mbox{$\ell$ odd}.
\label{IBparity}
bbnd{eqnarray}
For even $\ell$, $(-1)^{\nu F}a^{\ell}P_B$ breaks all supersymmetry
and the partition function is indeed a non-trivial function
of $\tau$.








\subsection{RCFT point of view}\label{sub:RCFT}

We next study the system in which a certain GSO projection is imposed.
The system can be regarded as
a rational conformal field theory, the crosscaps can be studied using the
standard procedure of Pradisi--Sagnotti--Stanev \cite{PSS}
which is reviewed (along with more recent developments such as 
\cite{HSS,FSHSS})
and extended in \cite{BH1}.





\subsubsection*{\it GSO projection}


We perform the GSO projection with respect to the operator
$$
(-1)^F=\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i (J_0-\widetilde{J}_0)}.
$$
This is a non-chiral projection and the
projected theory consists of NSNS as well as RR sectors,
in each of which only the states with $(-1)^F=1$ are kept.
RR and NSNS sectors correspond to the
twist parameters $(a,\widetilde{a})=(0,0)$ and
$({1\over 2},-{1\over 2})$ respectively, and
the GSO operator $(-1)^F$ is $\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i(s+\widetilde{s})/2}$
on the subspace $B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n,\widetilde{s}}$.
We therefore keep only the subspaces
$$
B_{j,n,s}\otimes B_{j,-n,\widetilde{s}},
\qquad
\mbox{with $s,\widetilde{s}\in \mathbb Z}$,~ $s+\widetilde{s}=0$ mod $4$,~
and $2j+n-s$ even.}
$$
Note that
$(-1)^F$ acts only on the Dirac fermions
$\Psi=(\psi_{\pm},\overline{\psi}_{\pm})$ and the GSO projection of the latter system
is equivalent to the rational $U(1)$ at level $2$,
the the circle sigma model of radius $R=\sqrt{2}$.
Thus the GSO projection of the full minimal model can be regarded as
the $SU(2)_k\times U(1)_2$ mod $U(1)$ gauged WZW model.
From this point of view, it is natural to group the spaces as
$$
\Scr{H}_{j,n,s}=\bigoplus_{p\in\mathbb Z}}B_{j,n,s+4p},
$$
where $s$ is now regarded as a mod $4$ integer.
The character $\chi_{jns}(\tau,u)$ that appears in (\ref{defcha})
is simply the trace on this space.
The Hilbert space of states of the GSO projected theory is expressed as
fbegin{equation}
{\cal H}^{\rm GSO} = \bigoplus_{(j,n,s)\in {\rm M}_k}
\Scr{H}_{j,n,s} \otimes \Scr{H}_{j,-n,-s},
end{equation}
where ${\rm M}_k$ is the set of $(j,n,s)\in {\rm P}_k\times\mathbb Z}\times \mathbb Z}_4$
modulo $\pi_1(H)\cong\mathbb Z}$, or more explicitly
$$
{\rm M}_k={\left\{\,\,(j,n,s)\in {\rm P}_k\times\mathbb Z}_{2(k+2)}\times \mathbb Z}_4\,\,\Bigl|\,\,
2j+n+s\,\,\mbox{even}\,\,
\right\}\over (j,n,s)\sim({k\over 2}-j,n+(k+2),s+2)}.
$$
In this subsection $n$ and $s$ are thus mod $2(k+2)$ and mod $2$ integers
that label $U(1)_{k+2}$ and $U(1)_2$ RCFT.
We usually assume them to be in the standard range 
$-k-1,\dots, k+2$ and $-1,0,1,2$, and
addition
modulo $2k+4$ (or modulo $4$ for $s$) is denoted by the symbol $\hat{+}$.
We often put hat $\widehat{n}$, $\widehat{s}$ to
the $U(1)_{k+2}$ and $U(1)_2$ labels $n$, $s$, to stress that they are
brought into the respective standard ranges.

\subsubsection{RCFT aspects of the theory}


\subsubsection*{\it Modular matrices}

The $S$- and $T$-matrices of the coset model have the factorized form
fbegin{equation}
S_{(j,n,s)(j',n',s')} = 2 \ S_{jj'} \ S^*_{nn'} \ S_{ss'},~~~
T_{(j,n,s),(j',n',s')}=T_{jj'}T^*_{nn'} T_{ss'},
\label{factorPF}
end{equation}
where it is understood that the matrices with
pure $j$ labels are those of the $SU(2)_k$
WZW model, matrices with pure $n$ or pure $s$ labels are
those of $U(1)_{k+2}$ or $U(1)_2$. 
Using this factorization property, we find
fbegin{equation}
N_{(j,n,s)(j',n',s')}^{\,\,\,(j'',n'',s'')}
=N_{jj'}^{\,\,j''}\delta_{n+n',n''}^{(2k+4)}\delta_{s+s',s''}^{(4)}
+N_{jj'}^{\,\,\frac{k}{2}-j''}\delta_{n+n',n''+k+2}^{(2k+4)}\delta_{s+s',s''+2}^{(4)}.
\label{paraN}
end{equation}
We also need to have expressions for
$P=\sqrt{T} S T^2 S \sqrt{T}$ and
$Y_{ab}^c=\sum_dS_{ad}P_{bd}P_{cd}^*/S_{0d}$.
$P$ relates the open and closed
string channel of the M\"obius strip and
$Y$ appears in the loop channel of the M\"obius strip and Klein bottle.
For the computation, it is useful to consider
$$
Q=ST^2S, \quad 
\tilde{Y}_{ab}^c = \sum_d \frac{S_{ab} Q_{bd}Q^*_{cd}}{S_{0d}}
=\sqrt{\frac{T_c}{T_b}} \ Y_{ab}^c.
$$
Thanks to the factorization of $S$ and $T$, we find
w
&&
Q_{(j,n,s)(j',n',s')} = Q_{jj'} Q_{nn'}^* Q_{ss'}+ 
Q_{\frac{k}{2}-j,j'} Q_{n\hat{+}(k+2),n'}^* Q_{s\hat{+}2,s'}
\\
&&
\tilde{Y}_{(j,n,s)(j',n',s')}^{(j'',n'',s'')} = \tilde{Y}_{jj'}^{j''} \
\overline{\tilde{Y}}_{nn'}^{n''} \tilde{Y}_{ss'}^{s''}+ 
\tilde{Y}_{jj'}^{\frac{k}{2}-j''} \
\overline{\tilde{Y}}_{nn'}^{n''+k+2} \tilde{Y}_{ss'}^{s''+2}.
bbnd{eqnarray}
 From this, one can compute $P=\sqrt{T}Q\sqrt{T}$ and
$Y_{ab}^{c}=\sqrt{T_b/T_c}\tilde{Y}_{ab}^c$, using the
following expressions for $\sqrt{T}$ in the coset model
fbegin{equation}\label{roott}
\sqrt{T_{j,n,s}} = \sigma_{j,n,s}\sqrt{ T_j T^*_n T_s},
end{equation}
where $\sigma$ is a sign factor defined by this equation and
explicitly computed in Appendix~\ref{app:weights}.

\subsubsection*{\it Discrete symmetries}

The group of simple currents is given by the primaries
$(0,n,s)$. For odd $k$ the symmetry group is $\mathbb Z}_{4k+8}$ and
is generated by $(0,1,1)$. For even $k$ it is $\mathbb Z}_{2k+4} \times \mathbb Z}_2$,
generated by $(0,1,1)$ and $(0,0,2)$.
The monodromy charge of the field $(j,n,s)$ under
the simple currents is 
fbegin{equation}
Q_{n,s}(j',n',s') = \frac{nn'}{2(k+2)} - \frac{ss'}{4} \ \ {\rm mod} \ 1 \ .
end{equation}
Accordingly, there is a symmetry action on states such that
fbegin{equation}
g_{n,s}=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i \left( \frac{nn'}{k+2} -\frac{ss'}{2}
\right)}\quad\mbox{on $\Scr{H}_{j',n',s'}\otimes\Scr{H}_{j',-n',-s'}$}
end{equation}
$g_{1,1}$ corresponds to the generator
$a=\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i J_0}$ of the axial rotations in the gauged WZW model;
$g_{0,2}$ is the element $(-1)^{\widehat{F}}$ that distinguishes the RR and
NSNS sectors.

\subsubsection*{\it Orbifold}

We consider the orbifold by the subgroup $\mathbb Z}_{k+2} \times \mathbb Z}_2$
generated by the currents $g_{2,0}$ and $g_{0,2}$,
whose space of states is 
fbegin{equation}
{\cal H}^M = \bigoplus_{(j,n,s)\in {\rm M}_k}
\Scr{H}_{j,n,s} \otimes \Scr{H}_{j,n,s}.
\label{orbi}
end{equation}
This can be regarded as the mirror of the original model.
The mirror map $\Psi: {\cal H} \to {\cal H}^M$ 
acts on states as
$\Psi=V_M \otimes 1: 
\rangle{j,n,s} \otimes \rangle{j,-n,-s} \to  \rangle{j,-n,-s} \otimes \rangle{j,-n,-s}$.


\subsubsection{A-type parities}

We now turn to the construction of the standard PSS parities and crosscaps,
which we shall call A-type crosscaps.
For each simple current $(0,n,s)$ there is a crosscap state
given by
fbegin{equation}
\rangle{\Scr{C}_{n,s}} = \sum_{(j',n',s')\in {\rm M}_k}
\frac{P_{(0,n,s)(j',n',s')}}{\sqrt{S_{(0,0,0)(j',n',s')}}} 
\ \vert \Scr{C},j',n',s'\rangle\!\rangle.
end{equation}
Explicit expressions for the A-type crosscap states can be found
in Appendix~\ref{app:cc}.
Note that the crosscap states with
$n$, $s$ even contain only Ishibashi states in the NSNS-sector, whereas
those with $n$, $s$ odd contain only Ishibashi states
in the RR-sector.
One can compute the Klein bottle amplitudes using the $Y$-tensor.
The result is
w
\lefteqn{\langle \Scr{C}_{\bar{n},\bar{s}}|\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2\tau}H}
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle
=}
\nonumber\\&&
\sigma_{0,\bar{n},\bar{s}}\sigma_{0,n,s}\delta^{(2)}_{\bar{n}+n}
 \delta^{(2)}_{\bar{s} +s}
\Biggl\{\,
\sum_{2j+\frac{\bar{n}-n}{2}+ \frac{\bar{s}-s}{2} \, {\rm even}}  
(-1)^{2j}(\chi_{j,\frac{\bar{n}-n}{2}, \frac{\bar{s}-s}{2}}
+ (-1)^s \chi_{j,\frac{\bar{n}-n}{2}, \frac{\bar{s}-s}{2}+2})(2\tau)
\nonumber\\
&&\qquad\qquad
 + \delta_k^{(2)} \,{\rm e}^{\frac{\pi i}{2} (-\bar{n}+\bar{s})}
( \chi_{\frac{k}{4}, \frac{\bar{n}-n}{2}+\frac{k+2}{2}, 
\frac{\bar{s}-s}{2}+1} + (-1)^s 
\chi_{\frac{k}{4}, \frac{\bar{n}-n}{2}+\frac{k+2}{2}, \frac{\bar{s}-s}{2}-1}
) (2\tau) \Biggr\}.
\nonumber\\
\label{atypekb}
bbnd{eqnarray}
For $n=\bar{n}$ and $s=\bar{s}$, this expression simplifies to
w
\lefteqn{\langle \Scr{C}_{n,s}|\,{\rm e}^{-{\pi i\over 2\tau}H}
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle}
\nonumber\\
&=& \sum_{j \in \mathbb Z} }  
(\chi_{j,0,0}+ (-1)^s\chi_{j,0,2}) (2\tau) 
 + \delta_k^{(2)}\,{\rm e}^{\frac{\pi i}{2} (-n+s)}
(\chi_{\frac{k}{4}, \frac{k+2}{2}, 1}+ (-1)^s
\chi_{\frac{k}{4}, \frac{k+2}{2}, -1})(2\tau).
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}
The crosscaps correspond to involutive parity symmetries
$P_{n,s}$ which are related among themselves as
$$
P_{n,s}=g_{n,s}P_{0,0}.
$$
The above expression for
the Klein bottle function
$\Tr P_{n,s}q^H=\langle \Scr{C}_{n,s}|q_t^H
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle$
is consistent with this relation.





\subsubsection{B-type parities}

Another class of crosscap states can be constructed
from A-type crosscap states in
the $G=\mathbb Z}_{k+2} \times \mathbb Z}_2$ orbifold model, 
with an application of the mirror map.
We shall call them B-type crosscaps.
We refer to \cite{BH1} for notation and conventions.
For an RCFT ${\cal C}$ with
the charge conjugation modular invariant partition function
there are $|G|$  A-type
crosscap states in the orbifold theory for each $G$-orbit of simple currents.
These crosscap states are given by
fbegin{equation}\label{orbicross}
\rangle{\Scr{C}_{P^{\theta}_{g'}}}^{{\cal C}/G}
= \frac{e^{i\omega_{g'}}}{\sqrt{|G|}} \sum_{g\in G}
e^{-\pi i (\theta(g)-\hat{Q}_{g'}(g))} \rangle{\Scr{C}_{P_{gg'}}}^{{\cal C}},
end{equation}
where $\hat{Q}_g(i):= h_g+h_i-h_{g(i)}$
and $g'$ is a fixed representative
of a simple current orbit.
$\theta$ is a solution to the constraint equation
fbegin{equation}
\theta(g_1g_2)= \theta(g_1) + \theta(g_2) -\hat{Q}_{g_2}(g_1)
+2q(g_1, g_2) \quad \quad {\rm mod} \, 2
end{equation}
where $q$ is a symmetric bilinear form of $G$
that determines the orbifold theory.
($q$ is a form obeying $q(g,g)=-h_g$ and 
$Q_{g_1}(g_2) = 2q(g_1,g_2)$ mod $1$.)
%There are $|G|$ solutions for $\theta$, which can be found by
%adding a solution of the homogenous equation $\theta(g_1g_2)=\theta(g_1)
%+\theta(g_2)$ to a fixed solution of the inhomogeneous equation.
The crosscap state corresponds to a parity symmetry
$P^{\theta}_{g'}$, which squares to
fbegin{equation}
(P_{g'}^\theta)^2 = \,{\rm e}^{2\pi i (\theta(g)-Q_{g'}(g))} \quad \quad
\mbox{on the $g$-twisted Hilbert space ${\cal H}_g$}.
end{equation}


We apply this construction to
the orbifold of ${\mathcal C}=SU(2)_k\times U(1)_2/U(1)_{k+2}$
by $G=\mathbb Z}_{k+2}\times\mathbb Z}_2$ with the Hilbert space (\ref{orbi}).
This is the orbifold with respect to
the bilinear form given by
fbegin{equation}
q(g_{n,s},g_{n',s'}) = \frac{nn'}{4(k+2)} - \frac{ss'}{8}.
end{equation}
($g_{n,s}$ is in $G$ if $n$ and $s$ are both even.)
We first need expressions modulo $2$ for $\hat{Q}_g(h)$.
The conformal weight of a simple current
$(0,n,s)$ with $(0,n,s) \neq (0,\pm 1, \mp 1)$ is given by
fbegin{equation}
h_{(0,n,s)} = -\frac{n^2}{4(k+2)} + \frac{s^2}{8} + \frac{|n|-|s|}{2}
\quad {\rm for} \quad (0,n,s) \neq (0,\pm 1, \mp 1).
end{equation}
Using this we find
w
\hat{Q}_{g_{n,s}}(g_{n',s'}) &=& h_{(0,n,s)} + h_{(0,n',s')}
- h_{(0,n\hat{+} n', s\hat{+} s')} \\ \nonumber
&=& -\frac{n^2}{4(k+2)} + \frac{s^2}{8}
-\frac{(n')^2}{4(k+2)} + \frac{(s')^2}{8}
+\frac{(n\hat{+} n')^2}{4(k+2)} - \frac{(s\hat{+} s')^2}{8} \\ \nonumber
&& ~~~~+\frac{1}{2} (|n| - |s| + |n'| - |s'| - |n\hat{+} n'| + |s \hat{+}s'|) \\ \nonumber
&=&
\frac{nn'}{2(k+2)} - \frac{ss'}{4} - \frac{n\hat{+} n'}{2}
+ \frac{n+n'}{2} + \frac{s\hat{+} s'}{2} - \frac{s+s'}{2} \\ \nonumber
&& ~~~~+  \frac{1}{2} (|n| - |s| + |n'| - |s'| - |n\hat{+} n'| + |s \hat{+}s'|)
bbnd{eqnarray}
In the last step, we have used  $n,n',s,s'$ even.
We thus conclude that
fbegin{equation}
\hat{Q}_{g_{n,s}}(g_{n',s'}) = \frac{nn'}{2(k+2)} - \frac{ss'}{4}
\quad {\rm mod} \, 2,
end{equation}
in particular $\hat{Q} = 2q$ mod $2$. Therefore, we obtain a homogeneous
equation for $\theta$, $\theta(gh) = \theta(g)+ \theta(h)$, whose
solutions are given by
fbegin{equation}
\theta_{rq} (g_{n,s}) = -\frac{rn}{k+2} + \frac{qs}{2} \ .
end{equation}
The set of simple currents $(0,n,s)$ splits up into two orbits
under the orbifold group $\mathbb Z}_{k+2} \times \mathbb Z}_2$. The first orbit is the one
of $(0,0,0)$, which contains only currents $(0,n,s)$ with $n,s$ even; the
other orbit is the one of $(0,1,1)$, which contains only currents with
$n,s$ odd. Accordingly, there are two types of crosscap states. 
Following the general procedure, one first constructs
A-type crosscaps in the orbifold and then applies the
mirror map. These steps are performed in the appendix, and here we
merely list the results. 
B-type crosscap states are labelled by an element $(r,q)\in \mathbb Z}_{k+2}\times
\mathbb Z}_2$ and an orbit label $p$ which can take the values $0$ and $1$.
They are given by
fbegin{equation}
\rangle{\Scr{C}_{rqp}}= (2(k+2))^{\frac{1}{4}} \sum_j 
\sigma_{j,-2r-p,-2q-p}
\frac{P_{j\frac{k}{2}}}{\sqrt{S_{0j}}} 
(-1)^{\frac{\widehat{2r+p}-p}{2}+q} 
\vert \Scr{C},j,2r+p,2q+p\rangle\!\rangle_B,
\label{Crqp}
end{equation}
where $P_{j\frac{k}{2}}$ is the $P$-matrix of the $SU(2)_k$-theory.
These states are elements of the sector twisted by $g_{4r+p,2p}$.
Hence, the square of the parity action $P_{rqp}$ is given as
fbegin{equation}\label{Psquare}
P_{rqp}^2 = g_{4r+2p, 2p}.
end{equation}




One can compute the Klein bottle amplitudes using the average formula
(\ref{orbicross}) and the results
for A-type Klein bottles (\ref{atypekb}).
The result is 
fbegin{equation}\label{rcftbkb}
\langle \Scr{C}_{rqp}
|e^{-\frac{\pi i}{2\tau}H}\rangle{\Scr{C}_{rqp}}  =
\sum_{(j,n,s)\in {\rm M}_k}
e^{\pi i \frac{\widehat{(2r+p)}n}{k+2}} \ 
\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i \frac{\widehat{(2q+p)}s}{2}}
\chi_{j,n,s}(2\tau) 
end{equation}
We also note that
$$
\langle \Scr{C}_{r,q,p}
|e^{-\frac{\pi i}{2\tau}H}\rangle{\Scr{C}_{r,q+1,p}} =0,
$$
because $\rangle{\Scr{C}_{r,q,p}}$
and $\rangle{\Scr{C}_{r,q+1,p}}$ belong to orthogonal subspaces.
The expression (\ref{rcftbkb}) for the Klein bottle function
$\Tr P_{rqp}q^H=\langle \Scr{C}_{rqp}
|q_t^H\rangle{\Scr{C}_{rqp}} $ implies the following relations
among the parities,
fbegin{equation}
P_{rqp}=g_{2r+p,2q+p}P_{000},
\label{procla}
end{equation}
at least in the action on closed string states.
This is also consistent with the square formula
(\ref{Psquare}).








\subsection{Crosscaps in the theory before GSO projection}
\label{sub:beGSO}

In the previous subsection, we  obtained the crosscaps
for the theory in which the non-chiral GSO projection is imposed.
In this subsection, we use this result to reconstruct the
crosscaps in the theory before the GSO projection.
This enables us to compute the overlaps with the supersymmetric
ground states, as well as to reproduce the Witten index with a twist
by supersymmetric parities.




GSO projection is in a sense an {\it orbifold} by the symmetry
$(-1)^F$ where NSNS and RR sectors are regarded as the untwisted and
twisted sectors respectively.
Thus, one can find the relation of the crosscaps
before and after the GSO projection by following the argument
used in finding the relation of crosscaps before and after orbifold
\cite{BH1}.
In this subsection, we shall refer to the theory before GSO projection
simply as `the theory' or `the ${\mathcal N}=2$ theory'
and the theory after GSO projection as
`the (GSO) projected theory' or `the RCFT'.
We shall also put a superscript `GSO' to the space of states, the crosscaps,
etc, of the projected theory.
Let $P$ be a parity of the theory, and consider the parity of
the projected theory induced from $P$. The twisted partition
function of the latter is
$$
\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}^{\rm GSO}}\!\!
Pq^H
={1\over 2}\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm NSNS}}\!\!
\left((1+(-1)^F)Pq^H\right)
+{1\over 2}\Tr\!\!\mathop{}_{{\mathcal H}_{\rm RR}}\!\!
\left((1+(-1)^F)Pq^H\right).
$$
Using (\ref{idNSNS}) and (\ref{idRR}), the four terms of the
right hand side can be expressed as
$$
{1\over 2}\langle\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}|q_t^H|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle
+{1\over 2}\langle\Scr{C}_{P}|q_t^H|\Scr{C}_{P}\rangle
+{1\over 2}\langle\Scr{C}_{P}|q_t^H|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle
+{1\over 2}\langle\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}|q_t^H|\Scr{C}_{P}\rangle.
$$
This shows that the crosscap of the projected theory
is given by
$$
|\Scr{C}_P\rangle^{\rm GSO}
=\,{\rm e}^{i\theta}\left[
{1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle
+{1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{P}\rangle\right].
$$
One may also consider the parity $(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P$ of the projected theory,
where $(-1)^{\widehat{F}}$ is $1$ on NSNS sector and $-1$ on RR sector.
Repeating the same procedure, we find
$$
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P}\rangle^{\rm GSO}
=\,{\rm e}^{i\theta'}\left[
{1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle
-{1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{P}\rangle\right].
$$
We would like to invert these equations
to express $|\Scr{C}_{P}\rangle$ and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle$
as linear combinations of $|\Scr{C}_P\rangle^{\rm GSO}$
and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P}\rangle^{\rm GSO}$, which we know from
the RCFT computation of the previous section.
However, in order to find the right combination
it is important to know the phases
$\,{\rm e}^{i\theta}$ and $\,{\rm e}^{i\theta'}$, but there is no canonical way
to fix them.
Moreover, the phases of the RCFT crosscaps
$|\Scr{C}_P\rangle^{\rm GSO}$
and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P}\rangle^{\rm GSO}$
are highly non-canonical.




\subsubsection{The right combination}\label{subsub:right}


In fact, one can overcome this difficulty by making use of one independent
constraint --- the supercurrent condition.
%This is the first thing we discuss below.
If $P$ is an $A_{\alpha,\beta}$-parity or
a $B_{\alpha,\beta}$-parity of the ${\mathcal N}=2$ theory,
the crosscap $|\Scr{C}_P\rangle$
obeys a certain supercurrent condition, which is satisfied
only for a particular linear combination of 
$|\Scr{C}_P\rangle^{\rm GSO}$
and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P}\rangle^{\rm GSO}$.
The other crosscap, $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP}\rangle$, obeys a different
condition which is satisfied by another linear combination.
In this way one can find the right linear combinations, up to an overall
phase.

In what follows we carry out this program.
It turns out that A-type (resp.~B-type) parities in the RCFT correspond
to $A_{\alpha,\beta}$-parities (resp.~$B_{\alpha,\beta}$-parities)
of the ${\mathcal N}=2$ theory.
We thus separate the discussions into the two types.


\subsubsection*{\it A-type}

A-type crosscaps in RCFT are the PSS crosscaps
$|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle$
labelled by simple currents, $(n,s)$ with $n+s$ even.
The symmetry $(-1)^{\widehat{F}}$ is nothing but the global symmetry
labelled by $(n,s)=(0,2)$. Thus, $|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle$
and $|\Scr{C}_{n,s+2}\rangle$ corresponds to
$|\Scr{C}_{P_{n,s}}\rangle^{\rm GSO}$
and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{\widehat{F}}P_{n,s}}\rangle^{\rm GSO}$ for a suitable
$P_{n,s}$. The task is to identify $P_{n,s}$ and find the right combination
to express $|\Scr{C}_{P_{n,s}}\rangle$
and $|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^{F}P_{n,s}}\rangle$.
Since $|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle$ belongs to NSNS-sector (resp.~RR-sector)
for even $s$ (resp. odd $s$),
$P_{n,s}$ squares to $(-1)^F$ if $s$ is even and it is involutive
if $s$ is odd.


The crosscap state of an $A_{\alpha,\beta}$-parity must
obey the supercurrent condition
(\ref{coCA}). In terms of the Fourier modes, it is
fbegin{equation}
G_r+i\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha}(-1)^{r+{\beta\over \pi}}\overline{\widetilde{G}}_{-r}=
\widetilde{G}_r-i\,{\rm e}^{-i\alpha}(-1)^{r+{\beta\over \pi}}\overline{G}_{-r}=0,
\quad\,
\mbox{$r\in \mathbb Z}-{\beta\over \pi}$.}
end{equation}
Let us put
fbegin{equation}
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}(\pm)\rangle:=
{1\over \sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{n,s}\rangle
\mp {1\over \sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{T_{0,n,s}}\over\sqrt{T_{0,n,s+2}}}
|\Scr{C}_{n,s+2}\rangle.
end{equation}
One can show that they obey the
conditions of the types described in the following
table
(see Appendix~\ref{app:SC} for the proof):
$$
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
&\mbox{$s$ odd}&\mbox{$s$ even}\\
\hline
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}(+)\rangle&A_{0,0}&A_{{\pi\over 2},{\pi\over 2}}\\
\hline
|\Scr{C}_{n,s}(-)\rangle&A_{{\pi\over 2},0}&A_{{\pi\over 2},-{\pi\over 2}}
\\
\hline
\end{array}
$$
We know that the $A_{0,0}$, $A_{{\pi\over 2},0}$,
$A_{{\pi\over 2},-{\pi\over 2}}$, $A_{{\pi\over 2},{\pi\over 2}}$-parities
of the theory
are $a^{\it even}P_A$, $(-1)^Fa^{\it even}P_A$,
$a^{\it odd}P_A$, $(-1)^Fa^{\it odd}P_A$ respectively.
We also know that the axial symmetry $a$
induces
the global symmetry of the projected theory
labelled by $(n,s)=(1,\pm 1)$.
These are enough to show that
w
&&
|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m}P_A}\rangle=|\Scr{C}_{2m-1,2m-1}(+)\rangle,
\label{CApa1}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m}P_A}\rangle
=|\Scr{C}_{2m-1,2m-1}(-)\rangle,
\label{CApa2}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m+1}P_A}\rangle=|\Scr{C}_{2m,2m}(-)\rangle,
\label{CApa3}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m+1}P_A}\rangle=|\Scr{C}_{2m,2m}(+)\rangle.
\label{CApa4}
bbnd{eqnarray}
The overall phases are not fixed by this argument.
Here we have chosen the ones that will be justified
by later computations.


\subsubsection*{\it B-type}


 
B-type crosscaps in RCFT are
$|\Scr{C}_{r,q,p}^B\rangle$ given in (\ref{Crqp})
labelled by $(r,q)\in\mathbb Z}_{k+2}\times \mathbb Z}_2$ and $p\in\{0,1\}$.
Combining the parity with $(-1)^{\widehat{F}}$ corresponds to the shift $q\to q+1$.
Thus, we need to find the right combinations of
$|\Scr{C}_{r,q,p}^B\rangle$
and $|\Scr{C}^B_{r,q+1,p}\rangle$.
Since $|\Scr{C}^B_{r,q,p}\rangle$ belongs to
the sector twisted by the symmetry labelled by $(n,s)=(4r+2p,2p)$,
it corresponds to the parity that
squares to $a^{4r}(-1)^F$ if $p=0$ and $a^{4r+2}$ if $p=1$.
This shows that $P_B^{r,q,p}$ is induced from
$a^{2r+p}P_B$ or $(-1)^F a^{2r+p}P_B$ (or those
combined with axial R-symmetry).




The supercurrent
condition on the crosscap state of a $B_{\alpha,\beta}$-parity
is (\ref{coCB}), or in terms of the Fourier modes
fbegin{equation}
G_r+i\,{\rm e}^{i\beta}(-1)^{r-{\alpha\over \pi}}\widetilde{G}_{-r}=
\overline{\widetilde{G}}_r-i\,{\rm e}^{i\beta}(-1)^{r-{\alpha\over \pi}}\overline{G}_{-r}=0,
\quad\,
\mbox{$r\in \mathbb Z}+{\alpha\over \pi}$.}
end{equation}
Let us put
fbegin{equation}
|\Scr{C}^B_{r,p}(\pm)\rangle:=
{1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}^B_{r,0, p}\rangle\pm 
{1\over\sqrt{2}}
{\sqrt{T_{2+p}^{(2)}}\over \sqrt{T^{(2)}_{p}}}
|\Scr{C}^B_{r,1,p}\rangle,
\label{BCexp}
end{equation}
where $\sqrt{T^{(2)}_{n}}=\,{\rm e}^{\pi i \hat{n}^2/8}$ is the square-root
of the T-matrix of rational $U(1)$ at level $2$.
One can show that $|\Scr{C}^B_{r,p}(\pm)\rangle$ obey the
conditions of the types described in the following
table
(see Appendix~\ref{app:SC} for the proof):
$$
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
&p=1&p=0\\
\hline
|\Scr{C}^B_{r,p}(+)\rangle&B_{0,0}&B_{{\pi\over 2},{\pi\over 2}}\\
\hline
|\Scr{C}^B_{r,p}(-)\rangle&B_{0,{\pi\over 2}}&B_{{\pi\over 2},-{\pi\over 2}}
\\
\hline
\end{array}
$$
Since $B_{0,0}$, $B_{0,{\pi\over 2}}$, $B_{{\pi\over 2},-{\pi\over 2}}$,
$B_{{\pi\over 2},{\pi\over 2}}$-parities are
$a^{\it odd}P_B$, $(-1)^Fa^{\it odd}P_B$,
$a^{\it even}P_B$, $(-1)^Fa^{\it even}P_B$, we can conclude that
w
&&
|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle=(-1)^m|\Scr{C}^B_{m,1}(+)\rangle,
\label{CBpa1}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle=|\Scr{C}^B_{m,1}(-)\rangle,
\label{CBpa2}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m}P_B}\rangle=(-1)^m|\Scr{C}^B_{m,0}(-)\rangle,
\label{CBpa3}
\\[0.2cm]
&&
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m}P_B}\rangle=|\Scr{C}^B_{m,0}(+)\rangle.
\label{CBpa4}
bbnd{eqnarray}
Again, the overall phases cannot be fixed by this argument.
The choice we made will be justified by later computations.



\subsubsection{Overlaps with supersymmetric ground states}


Using the above results, one can compute the overlaps of the
supersymmetric crosscaps and supersymmetric ground states.

\subsubsection*{\it A-parities}

To compute the overlaps of the crosscap for
the basic A-parity $P_A$ and the RR ground states
$|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}$ one has to read off the coefficient of
$\vert \Scr{C},j,-2j-1,-1\rangle\!\rangle$ in the expansion of
$|\Scr{C}_{-1,-1}(+)\rangle$.
Since $\sqrt{T_{0,-1,-1}/T_{0,-1,1}}=-1$ by supersymmetry,
the latter is $(|\Scr{C}_{-1,-1}\rangle+|\Scr{C}_{-1,1}\rangle)/\sqrt{2}$.
The result is
fbegin{equation}
{}^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\langle j|\Scr{C}_{P_A}\rangle
=\sqrt{2\over (k+2)\sin\bigl({\pi(2j+1)\over k+2}\bigr)}
\,{\rm e}^{\pi i(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}
\left\{
-i\delta_{2j+k}^{(2)}\sin\left(\mbox{${\pi(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}$}\right)
+\delta^{(2)}_{2j}\cos\left(\mbox{${\pi(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}$}\right)
\right\}.
\label{ovPj}
end{equation}
Also, we find
fbegin{equation}
\langle \Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP_A}|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}
=\sqrt{2\over (k+2)\sin\bigl({\pi(2j+1)\over k+2}\bigr)}
\,{\rm e}^{-\pi i(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}
\left\{
\delta_{2j+k}^{(2)}\sin\left(\mbox{${\pi(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}$}\right)
+i\delta^{(2)}_{2j}\cos\left(\mbox{${\pi(2j+1)\over 2(k+2)}$}\right)
\right\}.
\label{ovFPj}
end{equation}
For other A-parities the overlaps can be easily obtained by
using $|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m}P_A}\rangle=\pm a^m|\Scr{C}_{P_A}\rangle$,
w
&&{}^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\langle j|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m}P_A}\rangle
=\pm\,{\rm e}^{-2\pi i m ({2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2})}
{}^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}\langle j|\Scr{C}_{P_A}\rangle,
\nonumber\\
&&\langle \Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m}P_A}|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}
=\pm\,{\rm e}^{2\pi i m ({2j+1\over k+2}-{1\over 2})}
\langle \Scr{C}_{(-1)^FP_A}|j\rangle^{}_{{}_{\rm RR}}.
\nonumber
bbnd{eqnarray}

\subsubsection*{\it B-parities}

Since the B-parity $a^{2m+1}P_B$
squares to $a^{2(2m+1)}$, the crosscap state
belongs to the sector with the twist parameter $(a,\widetilde{a})=(2m+1,0)$.
Such a sector has a $(2,2)$ supersymmetry and has
a unique supersymmetric ground state $|{\rm G}\rangle_{2m+1,0}$
which is an element of
$B_{j_*,-2j_*-1,-1}\otimes B_{j_*,-2j_*-1,-1}$
where $j_*\in {\rm P}_k$ is defined by
$2j_*+1\equiv -(a+\widetilde{a})=-(2m+1)$ mod $(k+2)$.
Namely,
$$
j_*=\left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
{k\over 2}-m&\mbox{if\, $m=0,1,...,[{k\over 2}]$,}
\\
k+1-m&\mbox{if\, $m=[{k\over 2}]+1,...,k+1$.}
\end{array}\right.
$$
In the two cases, $(j_*,-2j_*-1,-1)$ are equivalent to
$(m,2m+1,1)$ and $(k+1-m,2m+1,-1)$ respectively.
We are interested in the overlaps of this ground state
$|{\rm G}\rangle_{a,\widetilde{a}}$ and the crosscap states
$$
\left.
\begin{array}{l}
|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle(-1)^m\\
|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle
\end{array}
\right\}
={1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{m,0,1}^B\rangle
\pm {1\over\sqrt{2}}|\Scr{C}_{m,1,1}^B\rangle.
$$
The overlaps are obtained by reading
the coefficient of
$\vert \Scr{C},m,2m+1,1\rangle\!\rangle$ or $\vert \Scr{C},k+1-m,2m+1,-1\rangle\!\rangle$ depending on
$m\equiv 0,1,...,[{k\over 2}]$
or $m\equiv [{k\over 2}]+1,...,k+1$ (mod $(k+2)$).
The result is
fbegin{equation}
{}_{2m+1,0}\langle {\rm G}|\Scr{C}_{a^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle
=\left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
(-1)^m\sqrt{\cot\left({\pi(2m+1)\over 2(k+2)}\right)}
&m\equiv 0,1,...,[{k\over 2}],\\
(-1)^{m+k+1}\sqrt{-\cot\left({\pi(2m+1)\over 2(k+2)}\right)}
&m\equiv [{k\over 2}]+1,...,k+1,
\end{array}
\right.
end{equation}
and
fbegin{equation}
{}_{2m+1,0}\langle{\rm G}|\Scr{C}_{(-1)^Fa^{2m+1}P_B}\rangle
=\left\{
\begin{array}{ll}
\sqrt{\cot\left({\pi(2m+1)\over 2(k+2)}\right)}
&m\equiv 0,1,...,[{k\over 2}],\\
(-1)^{k}\sqrt{-\cot\left({\pi(2m+1)\over 2(k+2)}\right)}
&m\equiv [{k\over 2}]+1,...,k+1.
\end{array}
\right.
